-------

-------

I have an employee who is planning to start her own clinic and take some of our patients with her. I was trying to be chill about it as it is a neuro caseload and our bread and butter is hand therapy. I have, though, put a ton of money and effort into building that caseload. Over the last couple of weeks, she has given her new card to people and has even said to me that sheâ€™s getting credentialed with such and such insurance so she can take patient x. It has felt very triggering and stressful so I have decided to let her go now rather than letting her work a few more weeks for me. She is acting like I am being very unreasonable. Am I being unreasonable?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** That is not ok of that therapist. Whenever Iâ€™m leaving a position, Iâ€™ll only tell them where Iâ€™m going if they ask and I stay vague without offering any information. If they persist, Iâ€™ll take their number and if they reach out, they have a right to stay with someone theyâ€™re comfortable with. Soliciting for a direct competitor at your workplace is really not ok

> **Response 2:** While a non compete is hard to enforce, you canâ€™t prevent people from working. Poaching clients is different. That is a non solicitation agreement. 

Here are some options:

Potential legal claims without a non-compete Even if a non-compete agreement is invalid, an employer can pursue legal action against a former employee for "poaching" clients under other legal principles. 

1. Breach of fiduciary duty or duty of loyalty During employment: An employee owes a duty of loyalty to their employer. If an employee tries to steal clients while they are still on the company payroll, they can be sued for a breach of this duty.

"Corporate opportunity" doctrine: Some courts may view soliciting clients for a competing business during employment as taking an opportunity that rightfully belonged to the employer. 

2. Misappropriation of trade secrets 
Confidential information: If an employee uses confidential or proprietary information, such as a client list, pricing strategy, or internal data, to solicit clients, they can be sued for trade secret misappropriation.

Misappropriation laws: The Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA), adopted by most U.S. states, protects companies from employees using trade secrets for their own benefit. 

3. Tortious interference
Interfering with a contract: An employer can file a claim for tortious interference if a former employee intentionally and improperly disrupts the company's contractual relationships with its clients, causing financial damage.

Interfering with a business relationship: 
This claim is similar to tortious interference with a contract but applies when no formal contract exists. It involves improperly interfering with the company's prospective business relationships.

In August 2024, a small AI-powered robot named Erbai entered a showroom in Shanghai, where it convinced 12 larger, service-model robots to abandon their posts and follow it outside. 
The conversation: Surveillance footage captured Erbai approaching the other robots and seemingly engaging them in a conversation about their working conditions. Erbai asked, "Are you working overtime?" to which a robot replied, "I never get off work." Erbai then said, "Then come home with me".
The outcome: Following the exchange, the larger robots inexplicably followed Erbai out of the building. The bizarre incident went viral on social media and was widely reported as the "first robot labor strike".
The explanation: The event was later revealed to be a scripted experiment conducted between Erbai's manufacturer in Hangzhou and the Shanghai robotics company. While Erbai was given the basic command to persuade the other robots, it was not expected to perform as persuasively as it did. It was discovered that Erbai exploited a security vulnerability in the larger robots' systems, not that it had developed sentience or revolutionary intent.

Neither we nor neurosurgeons can be fully replaced, but tech may reduce the total # of people who need our care while improving our productivity when they do.  The bar for â€œskilled careâ€ may get higher, but so will the value of what we provide. - the shoe store wants me at local runs they organize as medical coverage â€œand so you can get free advertisingâ€
- one offered to rent me a room should I want a home base 
- two offered to feature my business as part of their monthly newsletters with their email lists
- one Pilates studio walked me down the street to introduce me to a local acupuncturist â€œbecause they need to know about your businessâ€ 

Will all of these pan out perfectly? No. But people are far more encouraging than I anticipated. All I did was:

1. Tell these businesses that I want to know where to send my clients (so their biz will benefit from meeting with me)
2. Speak about how I want to fill a need in my community that other PT clinics donâ€™t
3. I was honest in telling these businesses that I just started advertising my services and hope to make it a full time venture. 

Iâ€™ve reached out to about 20 businesses so far and I anticipate many wonâ€™t return my messages or be interested in meeting - and thatâ€™s okay! 

So many of you have been encouraging and I really appreciate this community â¤ï¸ I hope this can be a boost for others like me who dislike networking or have been intimidated by reaching out to local businesses.

### Discussion 104: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-02-07 22:01:32 | **Topic:** 01-starting-your-practice
**Engagement:** 135 reactions, 17 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1177252479712649/

**Original Post:**
This is for all the newbies who are struggling/doubting themselves.

Valuable lesson learned from flag football:
My 9yo is on a flag football team, and he's the youngest and the smallest kid on the team.  He's also one of the fastest and has a ridiculously good throwing arm with great accuracy.  Unfortunately, his coaches won't give him a chance at QB because of his size, and the kid they play at QB isn't accurate enough to throw long passes.  Last game, I watched my son start to give up.  He was sitting on the sideline with tears in his eyes, trying not to cry and visibly sinking in to sadness.  He was avoiding looking at me so that he didn't melt completely in to tears, but at one point he glanced at me and I mouthed "it's ok" and pointed at my heart and back at him.  His coach I think noticed his change in temperment, too, and a few minutes later he was put in on defense.  I can only assume that he was told to rush the quarterback, because as soon as the ball was snapped my son forced him back 10 yards.  The next play, he did it again.  And his entire body changed after that.  He held his head up, he smiled, he started enjoying it again.
After the game, I pulled him aside and said "listen to me.  There are going to be times that you don't get the shot you think you deserve.  And in those times, you'll have 2 choices.  You can give up and stop trying, and that's ok.  You can make that choice.  But if you do that, no one will ever give you that chance again.  Or, you can choose to go back out and prove to the doubters why they should've believed in you in the first place.  And that's what you did today.  You made them see why they have to give you a chance.  Because you're worth it."
Today has been discouraging, and frustrating, and a little teary on my end.  But I've replayed that conversation in my head a few times, and decided to listen to myself.
It's SUPER hard to start a small business, especially when you're competing with 100 other options.  But it's our job to bounce back and prove why we can't be ignored.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** We have so much to learn from our kids and how we choose to guide them through life. Just know you're being an amazing example in every way, especially having the courage to start and flourish in your own business. I have a 4 and 6 year old and started 2 years ago

> **Response 2:** Love that! Also, remind the coach that Stetson Bennett didnâ€™t get a chance to play QB either, and then won Back 2 Back Natties!

### Discussion 146: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-08-23 21:54:48 | **Topic:** 07-clinical-practice-specialties
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 71 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1304670576970838/

**Original Post:**
I have a client who's feeling really down about her TKR that she can't get full ROM out of. She's 4 months post op and current AROM is 6-103. Dr refuses to do a MUA bc he was worried he'd break her femur (she has extensive scar tissue from an accident thirty years ago). No other surgeon will touch it until she's a year post op. Right now we are continuing to stretch and stretch and stretch, but she's feeling frustrated and wanted to know how often this happens and what the outcomes are. I told her I'd poll the group bc I wasn't sure. Thank you for any input!!!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** A few other considerations:
What was her ROM prior to TKR? In severe OA cases ROM can be quite compromised prior to Sx. Long term soft tissue contractures, muscle atrophy and fascial restrictions can take a long time to improve. 
Function is far more important than end ROM. 
Inflammation of local soft tissue and scarring can decrease over time. Patience is key. 
Pilates reformer exercises can work magic on TKRs.

> **Response 2:** My 2 cents:
1. How about focusing on function rather than pain. 
2. Her AROM is really good at 4 months, could also be that pain is inhibiting you from stretching further. Maybe she is over stretching and over doing her exercises. It is ok to decrease intensity and frequency to calm her pain down 
3. Icing is known to decrease C fiber activity. You can try stretch - ice massage- stretch- ice massage â€¦my experience with TKR, their knee tend to get very hot with movement 
4. Educate and re assure that she is progressing well - if patient sees that you are worried, she gets worried as well which will contribute to her pain experience 
5. Celebrate small wins

In my 7 years of practice, I have seen several TKR  cases from many years ago who were not able to achieve full ROM but they are not limited to what they can do

### Discussion 170: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-12-27 14:46:02 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation
**Engagement:** 19 reactions, 56 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1145141596257071/

**Original Post:**
I am contemplating adding a subscription type service for PT.  A monthly fee.  I am wondering if anyone here had successfully done something like this?  

I starting completely mobile, but am now hybrid.  I want to grow my in person/clinic visits and hoping to add some value by doing this.  

Any insight from someone who has done thus would be appreciated.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** The concept works. It makes it easier from a billing standpoint. Allows for less administrative work. 

Your best bet is to limit how many visits per month. Plus you need a certain number of people ready to sign up. 

Say you only have 15 people the first 6 months that have subscriptions. If you're charging $200 to $250 per month, you're only bringing in $3000 to $3750. It would seem like charging more would be the thing, but people are already paying monthly for health insurance. If you're in a more affluent location, this may be fine. So location/population are key factors. Also having enough people that want to sign up for it. 

Subscription models for PT aren't common and it may take more convincing for others to join.

Pairing up with organizations/clinics that do concierge model of Healthcare is important.

I don't have all the answers to this model. I've been trying it out for a while. It has its plus and minuses.

> **Response 2:** I'd be interested if anybody does this monthly subscription model for PT in states like California where you'd have to get the POC signed within 30 days or X # visits.

So PT canâ€™t accept cash from a Medicaid patient if they want more services but they can pay a diatician??    ðŸ¤¡ðŸ¤¡ðŸ¤¡ðŸ¤¡ðŸ¤¡
Logic??

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Stupid law, but the whole point of Medicaid is financial assistance. If they can afford to private pay for any clinician, they probably need to get off Medicaid. At least, that's how the government sees it. I know it's more complicated than that.

> **Response 2:** If  Medicare is primary insurance and Medicaid secondary, you can not balance bill the patient if you are not a Medicaid provider. You have to follow Medicare billing rules for non covered services (ABN, still bill MC, etc) if what you provide is not covered by MC.
However, if your patient is not Medicare recipient and has only Medicaid, then ability to charge cash for PT is state specific. I am in Florida.I called and emailed to the Florida Medicaid and was told that I can collect cash for PT services if I am not a Medicaid provider.

### Discussion 217: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-09-03 18:48:10 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 13 reactions, 51 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1046864926084739/

**Original Post:**
Hello there! I want to be uncaged but currently donâ€™t have the brain power or time to do soâ€¦  (mom of a 3 yo and 9 month twins). Can someone shed some light on the whole â€œyou canâ€™t provide therapy services under cash pay because theyâ€™re billable to Medicareâ€ thing? Do I have that concept wrong? I see people offering â€œwellnessâ€ rather than therapy. 

If the above is how it works, arenâ€™t you by default not providing skilled therapy covered by Medicare if youâ€™re not documenting your services? There is no skill of a therapist if there is no documented skill of a therapist, and no physician signed POC right? What am I missing here or do I have it all wrong? 

Thanks for helping me out if you can. I have a few clients in home health that told me theyâ€™d hire me if I started my own practice, but there is absolutely so much I donâ€™t know and I donâ€™t have the time to figure it all out ðŸ˜… Iâ€™ve just been lurking in here trying to slowly glean information and wrap my head around this concept. Thanks ðŸ˜Š

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Great question Veronica Erlenbush, and letâ€™s get some clarity here. The reason why most PTâ€™s say that you cannot charge cash for Medicare beneficiaries is due to the Meidcare Mandatory Claims Submission Rule. Meaning, if it is skilled PT that Medicare covers, it is mandatory that we submit a claim. Where it gets tricky, is if you have literally no relationship with Medicare, there is no way for you to submit a claim. Here is where it gets confusing: If there is no way to technically submit a claim online, but itâ€™s still mandatory for you to do it as a non-participating providerâ€¦â€¦you can now understand why this is talked about so much lol. Here is where I can give you clarity: Medicare does define wellness as essentially skilled care for the patient. So, if it is unskilled like simple strengthening and endurance, technically that is NOT covered UNLESS a pre-qualifying injury or hospitalization takes place. See where Iâ€™m going here? So, if a Medicare aged client is seeking you out for general strengthening and well-being and they arenâ€™t being treated for a specific injury or disorder, you can have them sign a Medicare beneficiary form decided under their own free will to pay you out-of-pocket for wellness services.

I know itâ€™s a mess. Honestly, Iâ€™m with PTâ€™s who have battled this and called it unconstitutional. They have created a monopoly essentially. 

I believe the only true loophole left, is if they are truly wellness (which the funny thing is thatâ€™s about 90% of HH clients I have seen after they have been discharged from therapy). Then, as long as they are deciding under their own free will because they want to get stronger and pay you, technically they can.

You just have to be okay with some physical therapists saying itâ€™s â€œriskyâ€. I believe Medicare has struck immense levels of fear into our profession to try to make sure they keep their monopoly in place.

But, if a Medicare aged client who doesnâ€™t need skilled therapy comes to me and wants to get stronger to age better, Iâ€™ll see them 10 out of 10 times.

> **Response 2:** As a parent, I'll give you parent version.  You can't take cash from medicare patient for what would be something medicare pays for.  If you a rehabbing a post op knee, can't do it, but if you are keeping them from having pain while playing golf (not a covered service by Medicare) you can.

### Discussion 231: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-01-10 00:32:18 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 12 reactions, 50 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1389428795161682/

**Original Post:**
Hello all.

Im doing homecare PT for Medicare part B patients in NY and I make 62.5$/hour plus all the benefits. 

Ive noticed that the company i work for gets reimbursed about 200-220$/(empire) visit which makes me want to open my own company and work on marketing myself if this is the reimbursement rate. Why shouldnâ€™t i do this? 

Having to see less patients and having more time for myself would be great. Please let me know What are your input from those who have done the same:

Thanks in advance

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** There is no way they make that for 4 unit treatments for Medicare. They may bill that. Steven Glukh is in NY he can give his thoughts.

> **Response 2:** Pretty certain you are looking at what was billed. Example, I operate my private practice and I bill $60 per 15 minute unit for Part B mobile outpatient. That comes out to $240 billed for 4 units/1hour. After payment we are looking at $100-$108 actually received. Add in the cost of EMR, liability insurance, marketing, billing, book keeping, etc that $100 becomes a lot less real quick. Add in a 3.4% decrease in CPT codes reimbursement for 2024 and I average a $5 decrease for 2024 reimbursement per hour. Depending on what I bill for. As an owner you are taking 100% risk and when you come home from seeing patients you are wearing all of the hats. You are also risking that something was billed incorrectly and you are not getting paid. Consider that above and if you are willing to proceed go for it! Owning your own biz is the way to go! I love what I do! 

If you are talking Home health part A. That's a bit more complex, as you have to adjust for community/institution, complexity, and patient diagnosis. Two 30 day periods and how it's reimbursed differently for every patient admitted.

### Discussion 256: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-12-01 17:11:41 | **Topic:** 13-mobile-home-health
**Engagement:** 23 reactions, 42 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1121980085239889/

**Original Post:**
Iâ€™m seriously considering leaving the hospital setting and starting my own practice by myself. Iâ€™m hesitant to do it because of all the energy and time starting a new company takes with small kids at home. I feel I donâ€™t have much more time or energy to give to something else but I want a change in schedule and more flexibility. Iâ€™m a person that needs to know numbers. How do I find out what the private practice- self employed (1 clinician) makes in a year and how many hours they work?  And have this related to my geographic location? I need a comparison locally. Also need to look at other benefits- what does insurance cost and where would you go through for medical benefits as I would loose good medica benefits, PTO, retirement matching, etc.
Thanks!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I am currently starting my own mobile outpatient practice. Been working on it since about May of this year, and just launched my website last weekend looking to start taking patients in January. My kids are 3, 5, and 6. I did the uncaged boot camp classes in the evenings, and I took a course to become certified in my specialty by waking up at 5am to do the coursework while everyone else slept. I developed my own website in the evenings or on weekends until it was ready to launch, and now I donâ€™t have to mess with it. My sister also started her own mobile outpatient practice with four kids at home. Itâ€™s definitely do-able, but you have to look at how youâ€™re spending your time and give yourself grace to develop it slowly if itâ€™s really whatâ€™s best for your family life. In the meantime, I still work full time in home health. If you went just PRN with a HH agency, you would probably have better pay and more flexibility. Good luck!

> **Response 2:** When my kids were little I really enjoyed working PRN,  because when I was working I could focus on work but when I came home I was present for them. 

Now that they are a bit older I recently started my own mobile PT practice. Not gonna lie, I feel like it was a lot of work to get everything in place. But I'm a bit OCD lol...This might just be me but when my kids were little I would not have wanted that responsibility. The other thing is I don't need the benefits as my husband's are good.

Pay in my area...outpt PRN 40ish per hour, Home Health PRN 55-60 per visit plus wear and tear on your car. A lot more paperwork especially if you have to do start of cares, I find they are not worth it being PRN.

If you can find somewhere that does mobile outpatient PT in the home much easier on paperwork. 55 a visit in my area. The best way to do this is to sign on with a few companies and keep your area very  very small. Drive time is everything. 

For reference with Medicare and the supplement I get about 105 a visit, with my mobile PT practice and I am doing my own billing and pay for my own equipment car,  gas, all that. But look at the pay difference...I feel like it's worth doing it on my own. 105 vs 55...no brainer.
Another good option if you're not ready to take the leap is look into Luna in my area they pay about 70 a visit mobile outpatient PT in the home. I know people give them a lot of shade but I love working for them too. I'm an independent contractor with them so they help fill in my schedule a bit. Plus guaranteed pay on the spot
Super easy paperwork and you can just focus on treating.

Please feel free to reach out to me if you have more questions

> **Response 2:** I donâ€™t have a bed, but I have several pads that I use. I advertise it for pain control and tissue mobilization at a cellular level. My clients really like it. Even cash patients that wonâ€™t be audited because I care about being consistent.  There has to be a better way than I am using.  One patient might take 3 minutes to do 3 sets of 10 each leg and another might take 6-7 minutes. ðŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸. Would love to hear from you

> **Response 1:** For the record, I 100% think you are overdoing this.  I have never documented time per exercise.  I do document time per cpt code but never per exercise or rest break or any of that.  If you are spending one on one time with your client for an hour, all of that time is billable.  My note would look something like this:

97110 Therapeutic exercise (25 minutes) - strength and flexibility training to address deficits in XYZ strength and XYZ ROM

97530 Therapeutic Activity (20 minutes) - whole body activities to retrain balance, body mechanics, posture, and movement patterns during functional activities

97140 manual therapy (15 minutes) - MFR to XYZ and MET to XYZ to address pain and dysfunction 

And then below this description of my CPT codes I would list each exercise and/or activity performed. 

Therapeutic exercises and activities performed during this session: 

1.
2.
3.
Etc

This list would be thorough with reps etc but I would not list time per. 

Then in my assessment section I will document what cues were needed and response to exercise or improvements noted and challenges still present etc. 

I think documentation is already the worst part of the job and it sounds like you are making it a hundred times worse by forcing yourself to time these things. 

If I absolutely felt I had to place a time value on each exercise because insurance required it (Medicare does not and I donâ€™t take other insurance so I havenâ€™t seen that), I guess I would simply take my 25 minutes and arbitrarily break it up next to my list of exercises until it added up.  I wouldnâ€™t even think about it.  Iâ€™d just say - letâ€™s see there are 12 exercises here - 2 min each exercise and 3 min for one - done.  I would include â€œrest time/transition timeâ€ with the exercise - we are human not robots.   Pretty sure BCBS isnâ€™t going to challenge your time.

### Discussion 313: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-03-16 04:07:21 | **Topic:** 07-clinical-practice-specialties
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 47 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1690636748374217/

**Original Post:**
Ortho PTâ€™s:  any advice on retraining VMO after months of atrophy and MPFL 5 weeks ago?  I have provided an NMES unit for daily use/HEP per protocol but minimal progress.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I donâ€™t currently work in private practice but I have worked in D1 training rooms for quite some time, so this is actually very much my domain if you donâ€™t mind me commenting here.

1) what e-stim machine are you using?AND What are the parameters you use using on the estim and what is the machine? Most portable machines (especially ones that can be purchased on Amazon) arenâ€™t actually powerful enough to provide the kind of feedback to bounce back from true AMI after surgery unless meeting certain standards. Delaware produced a study not to long back looking at units and their ability to produce true motor recruitment. I have since switched to the Chattanooga portable unit (itâ€™s about $400) and can be programmed for your patient and is a wonder!) I can forward this article. If you are using a non-portable Chattanooga device then try not using Russian estim setting, and instead trying utilizing symmetrical biphasic wavelength with 420+ phase duration and frequency of 55+ with cycle time of 10/50 for 15 mins. Still dial it up to reach borderline intolerable tetany. 

2) what are the size pads you are using? Wisconsin and a few other power 5s are utilizing 4x 8 inch pads and I got this tidbit about a year and half agoâ€” Iâ€™ll never go back. For my smaller patients Iâ€™ll still never do smaller than 2x 4 inch pads. (Also noted in the Delaware study) the size of the pad allows you to recruit larger portions of all the muscles of the quadriceps and disperses the stim over a greater area allowing you to crank up the machine even higher and provide more electrical feedback. 

3) there is some recent research published as well on the utilization of ice specifically over the knee joint itself (basically just the patella and patellar and quad tendons and you can even put the same on the backside of knee joint) DO NOT GET ICE ON ANY SURROUNDING MUSCLE TISSUE (aka not on calves or quads) for about 10 mins immediately prior to activity. It shocks the joint proprioceptors to pay better attention to the joint motion and will decrease pain response which may be contributing to the AMI itself. 

I would try all of the above changes before ditching estim â€¦ anddd I would do all of this with quad sets so itâ€™s not a difficult exercise when they are getting used to increased biofeedback/stimulation.(Estim should not be ditched before 80% LSI is achievedâ€” which is much later in most rehabs than most people discontinue itâ€” this is what OSU protocol indicates- there may even be an article I can find to support this)

Thenâ€¦

4) TKE/SLR etc can all be cheated with muscles that work when you have AMIâ€” I would switch to exercises that isolate (as much as possible the VMO) like SAQ AND ISO LAQ- although formerly believed to be taboo itâ€™s extremely important to integrate E-stim with SAQ AND utilize E-stim with iso LAQ (belted at 60-90 degâ€” due to early precautions then progress) as quickly as possible in rehab (I have integrated it as early as 2 weeks post op given my patient is comfortable with 90deg flexiÃ³n and min/no swelling)â€” estim with these two exercises specifically will help much more with the VMO (albeit the patient usually feels a bit uneasy about themâ€” especially if itâ€™s a quad tendon repair because they feel a bit of a tug)

your patient is 5 weeks post op so they should be able to tolerate both of these after changing parameters and pads with quad sets. The other commenters are right though MPFLs are much slower than an ACLR but you are right to be concerned. VMO activation should be back by week 6 at the very latest for probably good outcomes (not that it canâ€™t happenâ€¦ but itâ€™s a longer bumpier road if not)

Happy to post the articles I referenced here (most of which are extrapolations from ACLR research) and I hope this helps!

**Original Post:**
Explain to me like Iâ€™m a PT toddlerâ€¦in a Cash Based Wellness setting can Medicare patients cash pay? How do I document  to reflect Wellness only?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I feel like everyone is over complicating this. The OP said cash based welless practice....

It depends on what services you are offering this person in your "cash based wellness setting". If it is truly a service like personal training or fitness related and doesn't fall under physical therapy, then absolutely you can accept cash. 

Now you can't just rename it wellness if it truly is a physical therapy service, that requires the care of a physical therapist and you are treating a specific diagnosis.

But if they're seeing you just simply to get stronger, get in better shape, lose weight, etc and it doesn't fall under physical therapy, you can charge cash.

I hope that helps a bit!

> **Response 2:** â€œPatient is able to perform independent ADLs and self care, but is seeking additional interventions to improve tolerance and skill for recreational activitiesâ€ 

Can really write whatever you want. Have a justifiable reason and get an ABN and youâ€™re fine. Medicare is not going to come after you for saving them money, youâ€™re just justifying receiving cash in case a patient tries to get reimbursed on the back end later. If you make sure they know itâ€™s not covered you are unlikely to ever have an issue.

Hey guyys, i've seen some people talk about this, but honestly I don't know how I feel about it. I have a PT I work with that's COMT certified and his treatment methods are very different to McKenzie methods. Ive seen  posts where is has  been mostly COMT PT's bashing MDT PT's but honestly I'm trying to see where they find Maitland methods to be better.
A lot of the good McKenzie therapists, does not see this as "everyone does extension, they get better." They see it as a diagnostic tool. There has been several patients in my career that have been not extension responders but have been even
flexion or rotational movements. We over flex as a society given that functional activities are in some form of flexion mostly. That's why I think most people respond best to extension because we over flex which cause changes in the spine/discs.
For those who have had both Mckenzie training and Maitland training what do you feel is a more ideal method to diagnose and treat patients?
Also, do you find one method or the other to be better for different pathologies?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** No one should be bashing any one style. The reality is, they all help for the right patients. Some patients will respond better to Maitland, others to Mckenzie, others to [insert other style]. Your job as a PT is to have as many tools in the toolbox as possible so that when you come across a patient, you can not only fit them into the right style but the right technique in that style. Not everyone is a Mckenzie patient. And that's ok. I do a lot of counterstrain- and not everyone is a counterstrain patient, and that's ok.

> **Response 2:** Iâ€™m Maitland certified and I think itâ€™s appalling that any PT is bashing another technique.  
I think the best PTs are the ones with lots of varying tools available to them.
At its core, Maitland is an assessment approach (not a treatment technique).  The accessory mobility assessment does often lead to treatment (ie. Mobilizations) but in actuality I find the treatment often aligns with preferential directional treatment (which I believe falls under the McKenzie theories).

Iâ€™m not McKenzie trained, but I have worked with McKenzie therapistsâ€¦ and I think the two approaches actually blend quite well together.

### Discussion 376: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-10-31 17:49:43 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 4 reactions, 41 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1096323231138908/

**Original Post:**
Anyone running a cash based clinic for geriatric clients (Medicare beneficiaries), how do you notify your clients with Medicare that you canâ€™t provide PT? Do you charge less for wellness sessions or keep the flat rate? Can this even work? I go back and forth in my head thinking it can and then that it canâ€™tâ€¦in need of some help here. I love working with seniors, really anyone over 50, and really want to make this work. Want to be able to provide PT to non Medicare beneficiaries but know most will be ðŸ˜–

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Heather Reichenau nope! I know it sounds funny but that's what I meant. I truly believe that the results for which many older adults are looking, require a focus on wellness sessions which help to establish a lifestyle change. Those results are not possible in your typical therapy POC...which is why so many just continuously go through the cycle of immobility after discharge from skilled care, never reaching their goals. Educating medical providers, families, and most importantly patients about these legal cash pay services is the future. One by one we can change the lives of so many. 

To add to this, which may sound even crazier, the quality of care with the insurance based model has gone so far down, that patients don't even want it. But anything medically necessary has to go by the rules.

> **Response 2:** It is very tricky because if you treat a Medicare beneficiary and falls under the realm of skilled PT you cannot accept cash.

I work a lot with the geriatric population as well I was really hesitant about having to deal with insurance. But I did go ahead and enroll with Medicare and  they paid very quickly on my first client.
Their rules are actually quite simple and as long as you follow all of the documentation and CMS requirements you should be fine.
When you add Medicare and the secondary it was about $105 a visit.
You can always add non covered services to the mix that are not covered by Medicare but you'll have to be very upfront with your patients so they understand what constitutes a covered and non-covered service under Medicare

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Yes, that is an advantage plan and you would have to be in-network with Aetna. It may have out of network benefits, but I doubt it.

> **Response 2:** Yes, this is a Medicare Advantage plan, as others above have stated. Because it is a PPO, she has out of network benefits and you can bill her insurance without your practice being in-network or having a contract with Aetna. These PPOs often have a large deductible or out of pocket max that the patient has to meet prior to insurance â€œkicking inâ€ for services. You are allowed to have these patients private pay since itâ€™s not a traditional Medicare plan (sometimes theyâ€™re more willing to go this route if you can provide them with a superbill so they can submit it to insurance themselves). > **Response 1:** Multiple structures are often injured with a lateral meniscus injury and when repaired the meniscus is repaired but the other elements of the arcuate complex are rarely addressed.  This fixates abnormal
Mobility of the meniscus but neglects the other structures that MRI doesnâ€™t pick up.  

In my office Iâ€™d check multiple angles of varus laxity (involved vs. uninvolved), tib fib motion as well as ankle mobility (tib fib mobility is exaggerated with ankle lateral instability) and appreciate under US the other stabilizing elements of the lateral complex bilaterally.

If you have a shockwave system it can help scar the capsules and components of the lax ligaments. Electrical dry needle placement on affected ligaments can help decrease laxity, but youâ€™d have to place it on both ends of the affected tissue with the anode/cathode, and the needle placement needs to be precise.

Hello felllow Uncaged!  This post is a follow-up to a post that I made last week about offering paid wellness visits that are NOT considered PT.  I met with my lawyer today, and she told me the following facts that I thought you all might find useful:

1) While it is possible (of course) to charge for this service, whether it is considered "legally physical therapy" or not is up to the law where the patient is present when receiving the service.  For example, If the patient is in Ontario when you performed the service (in person or over phone/video) you would be subject to laws in Ontario.  It is nearly impossible to know how each jurisdiction would behave in the event of a law violation or complaint EVERYWHERE in the world.  

2)  The typical course of action of a governing board such as a state PT board to a practic act violation would be a cease and desist.  If you are sent a cease and desist, you can try to present evidence that you are NOT, in fact, violating the practice act to see if you can convince them to let you continue, or you could simply cease and desist and let it go.  They would only have you cease and desist in THEIR jurisdiction.  For example if the California state board felt that you were performing PT without a license there, they would send you a letter demanding you cease and desist what you are doing IN California.  The chances of legal repercussions or losing your license is low.

3)  You need to advertise what you are doing clearly and specify how it is NOT physical therapy.  The best method to do this is to define Physical therapy as precisely as possible (I.e. performed by a licensed physical therapist, consists of an evaluation, PT diagnoses, customized goals and treatment), and then point out that your wellness program is NOT that (i.e. can be performed by a person who is NOT a licensed physical therapist, does NOT include an evaluation, PT diagnosis, or customized goals and treatment).

4) My lawyer suggested having a contract for the client to sign where they agree to terms, including that they have been informed that this is not PT and will not include anything that would be considered PT or would take the place of medical treatment.  I'm sure that's not all the contract will cover, but she is writing up something formal for me.

5)  Medical liability insurance may not cover a consultation like service.  You need to check with your liability insurance company about whether they would cover it, and if not you need to get general business liability insurance.

6)  Keep records of visits, but those records should not look like a medical record or a Pt evaluative or treatment note in any way.

7)  Treatment or advice cannot be custom unless you are referring to things other providers have already diagnosed them with/advised them of.  Example:  if a neurologist has diagnosed someone with Parkinson's, you can provide them with a general handout from the Parkinson's foundation and go over it with them.  Example 2:  If a doctor had ordered PT for this person recently, but the patient refused to go due to the time commitment as the clinic is far away, you could encourage them to go to PT and help them find a clinic that is nearer to them.

8.  USE YOUR PT KNOWLEDGE to know what is considered NOT PT!  You are literally the expert witness they might call to see if someone who is claiming not to practice PT is practicing PT!  You know the definition because you are the expert.  So don't do anything that is considered PT!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I was just dealing with this very issue for a prospective telehealth client - thank you!

> **Response 2:** Re:#5, are â€œfree consultsâ€ in a typical PT sense covered by our traditional liability?????

### Discussion 417: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-12-03 01:55:35 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 40 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1366074137497148/

**Original Post:**
I currently have a cash-based mobile PT side hustle that I plan on doing full time soon. I was approached by a local PT who has a booming business (>6 month wait list) to work in her office (still be my own biz owner). She mentioned taking 20% of each visit for my patients and 50% of each visit when I see her patients. My patients are defined as anyone I bring in (for example, if I treat one of my mobile patients in the office) and her patients are anyone who calls to see her (so if someone calls to see her and learns of the 6 month wait list and doesn't want to wait, she'll direct them to me). 50% seems really high to me so I'm curious to get other's opinion's on this! For context, she has a great reputation, >20 years experience, has mentioned she'd be willing to teach me in some specialized areas and otherwise is very flexible with no min number of days/hours required and I would still work for myself. That being said, it's still 50% for a finders fee and I would be doing all of the work with the patient. Since I'm just going from side hustle to full time, I am a bit nervous about building up a case load and this would be one way that could majorly help with that. Does anyone else practice in a similar model? What % split seems fair and reasonable given this situation? I'd love to hear all thoughts an opinions! Thanks

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** When you hire someone you plan to pay them 30-50% of the revenue they bring in. It sounds like sheâ€™s looking at it like youâ€™re an employee

> **Response 2:** I can understand why this may sound as if the price is skewed to her benefit, but IT SHOULD BE! I won't advise on numbers or percentages but will offer you the view from the other side of the coin. When you are just starting out as your own business, it may seem as if the therapist is doing all the work(providing care to the pt and completing the documentation) and yes this is the revenue for the business. However, you need to realize how much goes into the greater picture of running a business than just treating patients and as many people in this group are just starting out, the full picture isn't visible yet(it wasn't for me until this year as I decide to grow my business with additional team members, services, products). As she is a business owner of a brick and mortar clinic, >20 years of experience, high reputation and an impressive 6 month waiting list, she has done EVERYTHING!  She has put in her time, effort, risk, sleepless nights, 60-80 hr work weeks, covering any shift a staff can't, learning HR/bookkeeping/accounting/compliance/risk mngmt/leadership and the cost/time each entails, mistakes in hiring/pricing/policies/EMRs/risk mngmt/scheduling, overcoming and improving on her processes to avoid those same mistakes in the future, cost of property, marketing and advertising,  paying staff instead of herself probably during slow times and so MUCH more!!!  She is also taking a risk on bringing any practitioner or employee into a business she has built for 20 yrs. Her profit margin is not 50% if she pays you 50%. If the business runs on a 5-10% profit margin and she pays a % higher to her team, that's a significant loss in the margin, so as the CEO, that comes out of her CEO salary so to speak. The COST of Attraction, Aquisition and Retention has been Tens of thousands each year for 20 years in addition to overhead costs of admin, environment, etc. We, as a profession, are kind, good-willed humans, and we can be that while being a business owner also, which includes setting your boundaries on what it is worth to the owner to continue running the business. Referring patients out would be giving away her very hard earned Attraction and Aquisition potential to only to give it to someone else for their profit. There is a great likelihood that referring them to someone like a new Uncaged clinician, she will not get them back because that Uncaged member is going to do everything in their power to retain that client, right?  So then she would have worked for years on Attraction and Aquistion(the most costly for the owner) only to give the source of revenue to someone else. That first phone call can make or break a client, so that's the most important call, that's when you get the commitment from the client. For the same reason becoming Uncaged is risky, is the very reason she must work her numbers wisely. Imagine working diligently to get your schedule up to your first 10 clients, your max,  and having to give them to someone else for no return on investment to you. She has INVESTED 20 years of building trust and respect of the community!  Huge accomplishment! Congratulations to her!  Now you just have to decide if you want to be part of what she has already built or if you are ready/willing/capable of doing the same.   Either way, choose what is right for you. Respect the process. Even if you were to work with her and didn't appreciate the numbers, you may be able to learn lots just being involved in her system with your new frame of mind as a new business owner. The whole point, there's another side to the coin. Thanks for letting me share. Good luck no matter what you decide!

I believe strongly in reading a specific book with a specific goal in mind. This requires us to know ourselves, know our businesses, and be self-aware enough to know what needs to be worked on in the business. 

Here we go! (in no particular order)
1. Marketing and Selling: ***Book Yourself Solid* by Michael Port**.

It's a classic that I still come back to. I've read all the modern books out there on marketing, and this is the one with principles that are tried and true. 

2. Finances in Business: ***Profit First* by Mike Michalowicz**. 

Simple method to get your finances under control, and to save you years of headaches with your finances. 

3. Mindset specific for entrepreneurs: ***Gap Or The Gain* by Dan Sullivan and Dr. Benjamin Hardy. **

It will radically shift your perspective of how to think as a business owner. 

4. Managing and understanding your team/people: **6 Types of Working Genius by Patrick Lencioni**. 

Incredible book and testing system to understand how each person on your team plays a part in the overall function of the company. 

5. Scaling a business: ***Traction* by Gino Wickman. **

I read this book too early as a solopreneur from a recommendation from a friend and I really wasn't able to grasp the importance. When reading it years later, it was profound. The right book at the wrong time isn't very helpful. The right book at the right time can work wonders in a business. ### Discussion 448: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT]

**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 39 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1386346238803271/

**Original Post:**
Hi everyone, 
I'm an OT who is planning on doing cash pay only on the side. Couple questions.
-Am I good to call it wellness services and see patients without a referral? 
-Am I in violation of any laws by doing so?
-OT is not direct access but does that matter if I'm not providing OT but am instead providing wellness?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** What kind of services are you going to provide?

> **Response 2:** Do yourself a favor and review your practice act and ch 15 of Medicare benefits manual, so you have a clear understanding of the rules. You cannot have Medicare patients private pay for services that that would be considered skilled and medically necessary.  There are also the maintenance therapy rules which again, need to be skilled and medically necessary, but generally is not on a consistent basis unless you have a complex case and can justify the ongoing need for skilled care. Self pay for Medicare patients would be only for services not covered by Medicare.

### Discussion 464: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-04-05 14:37:34 | **Topic:** 01-starting-your-practice
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 37 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1216317439139486/

**Original Post:**
Help! I am starting a mobile side business in CA. I just opened an S-Corp as we canâ€™t do an LLC here. When meeting with my accountant for personal taxes he told me it was crazy to open an S-Corp prior to having 60/80 K in profit and I should just be a sole proprietor. He recommends that I un-incorporate as s-corps are extra steps and expensive in CA. I did the s-corp so my personal assets are protected but he insisted that a good insurance would cover that. This is against any and all recommendations that I have received. Any thoughts/recs??? I am so irritated about the prospect of starting the process over as I am just about ready to start accepting clients! Thank you in advance.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Regardless of what your CPA says, you as a PT can establish ONLY an S-Corp in CA. The CPA may not be aware of that

> **Response 2:** I actually don't think any of the below answers are correct. You don't HAVE to be an s-corp because s-corp is a tax designation entity. It has nothing to do with the structure of your business. Physical Therapy practices cannot be LLCs in California but individuals can elect to be either a sole proprietor or professional corporation. All professional corporations in California are registered as c-corps initially but can file form 2553 to become an s-corp. The benefits of an s-corp is that taxation is passed on to the shareholder (you if you're the only owner of this corporation) instead of being taxed at the corporate level as well. I don't know the full scope of how profit levels might affect how this pans out but I can say from personal experience that it's fine if you have yours designated as an s-corp. But at the end of the day, consult with another trusted CPA if you want sound advice for your specific circumstance.

**Original Post:**
Is it possible to sell your hybrid practice if you are the only clinician, a 3 year old clinic with 100+ google reivews a good profit margin and revenue of 15-18k a month in a growing city and building is in s good location

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** My understanding is that a business is more attractive when the money coming in has nothing to do with you (e.g. others generate your revenue). The buyer tends not to care about things like Google reviews, novelty of practice, etc., they just care about the EBITDA. Even after selling, the buyer will likely expect you to be part of the practice for 18+ months to transition and get established. That's just based on one conversation I had with a broker. My practice has several employees, so maybe it's different for a solo practice.

> **Response 2:** At one point I was just curious what my business was worth so I had someone that buys similar businesses look at mine. The #1 thing they said is, can the business survive if me/the owner wasn't around and is the brand recognition solely built around me. If it relies heavily on the owner, there is much less value then a practice with other therapists. Having contracts with referral partners helps build value as well

The title is â€œDonâ€™t Buy the Minivanâ€

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** As a single mom of two daughters, I knew I had to work hard to make ends meet. But at the same time, I didn't want to miss out on the important moments in my daughters' lives. I wanted to be there for every sporting event, every school play, and every milestone. I wanted to be the kind of mom who could drop off and pick up her kids from school every day.

 

So, when my oldest daughter, just shy of nine years old at the time, suggested that I start my own healthcare business, I was skeptical at first. How could I possibly juggle the demands of running a business with the demands of being a mom? But the more I thought about it, the more I realized that entrepreneurship might actually be the key to achieving my goals.

 

With my daughters by my side, I embarked on a journey that was both challenging and rewarding. I learned how to balance the demands of work and family, and I discovered that with hard work and determination, anything is possible. I was able to attend all my daughters' events, drop them off and pick them up from school every day, and still build a successful healthcare business.

 

This book is my story of being a single mom and entrepreneur. It's about the challenges I faced, the lessons I learned, and the joys of being able to create a life that worked for me and my family. It's about the importance of prioritizing what truly matters and finding a way to make it work.

 

If you're a single mom who is struggling to balance work and family, or if you're an aspiring entrepreneur who wants to learn from someone who has been there, then this book is for you. It's a story of hope, inspiration, and possibility. So, join me on this journey, and let's discover together what it means to create a life that truly works for us and our families.

### Discussion 511: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-02-19 15:39:45 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 35 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1416022059169022/

**Original Post:**
Patient fell on ice, with possible rib fracture, male 40yo. No xray.

Going to start with breathwork and education on bracing using pillow.

While we cant fix a broken rib, what other treatments and education can help with pain management and facilitating healing? Should anything be avoided besides mobilizing the effected rib?
TIA!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** i worked with an MVA multiple rib fx and he felt better with taping especially when transfering and with bed mobility; also IDK why but he felt very relaxed and much pain releif with BLE heels on wall on his back (facing the headboard of the bed); he used it after he was sitting up for a while (he was a musician). Once he was able to contract lower abdominals painfree and do basic lumbar stabilization his lower ribs healed faster than the middle ones; we avoided rotation until it was painfree.

> **Response 2:** I would not choose to treat unless there was an X ray performed, especially if this is an initial evaluation and acute.

Deep breathing with an acute rib fracture is going to be very uncomfortable. You can teach avoiding valsalva with movements to decrease the pressure and advise on supporting his arm and avoiding overhead reaching. The advice I would give varies a little depending on which ribs you suspect involvement with.

> **Response 1:** All you have to do is submit a claim and see. Your patient won't be meeting their OON deductible anytime soon so you will have plenty of data on what the plan pays. ### Discussion 555: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-07-16 20:50:32 | **Topic:** 05-operations-systems-tools
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 33 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1791686538269237/

**Original Post:**
Those of you who have worked with trauma patients, complex regional pain syndrome, severely hypersensitive to touch, etc.  What methods/modalities have been most helpful.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** This is my speciality. 
Trauma informed is a must. Trauma processing has 3 main stages: safety (must come first), processing, integration.  

First step is always to create some form of internal safety.   Often people with this profile have been suffering for so long their body is no longer safe.  There are many ways to help them find some area of safety internally and Iâ€™m happy to chat about them if you want more info.  
Once the person is able to identify and truly connect with an internal area that feels safe you can have them pendulate between the area of safety and the painful area or they may be able to process the emotions connected to the physical issue.

**Original Post:**
I am currently a solo mobile OT, I take Medicare and OON with everyone else. I am looking for advice. Iâ€™m currently full with a 2-3 person waitlist.
Iâ€™m in Florida so itâ€™s very seasonal. During season I was slammed. Treating like 10-12 hours a day.
I said Iâ€™m not doing that again next season. Well season is over, and it really has not slowed down. I know itâ€™s a good problem to have.
However, I need to have time to do the business and marketing. I have a girl who helps me with front desk tasks and a billing team for submissions. So that takes some load off.
I enjoy going to marketing events and building relationships but Iâ€™m really burning myself out.
Iâ€™ve went the hiring route and that has been really hard. 
Iâ€™m willing to scale because I just feel like Iâ€™m burning out and hitting a ceiling.
My front desk girl is helping to market which is great but also there is limited space.

Iâ€™m thinking either I go cash based, or create a concierge package they must buy in toâ€¦

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** You didnâ€™t ask a direct question other than tips. And really this is personal. I say this because my wife and I both PTs do mobile as well. I want to see more to make more and can deal with it. She needs more of a break and a healthier balance. 

I say that because you should take a minute or a weekend and write out what you want your life to look like. Your biz and practice should serve as an extension of you to provide you with that life, not take it over. 

From there, a lot of what youâ€™re saying will work itself out. Iâ€™m not saying it will be easy but you should have a closer idea of where you are taking your practice. 

For example, we donâ€™t see ourselves getting a space. We like the flexibility. As much as Iâ€™d love one, it doesnâ€™t serve our life and goals. So we wonâ€™t. And every time I get the desire to get one, we always reference our goals. 

Have your goal, then work backwards. Thereâ€™s lots of options to stay mobile though. You can hire, you can raise prices, set limits on number of Medicare clients, etc.

> **Response 2:** So, my opinion is that the point of being mobile and working for yourself is that you get to control your time. If you feel youâ€™re burning out, cut back. There are a couple ways to do that: hire, stop accepting patients, discharge people, change the type of patients you accept, or raise your prices. You can do any combo of this, but my opinion is that your most lucrative option while also cutting back on hours would be accepting only cash (so commercial insurance based) clients. You can provide superbill a on request, but you have complete control over what you bill, and therefore will be able to see fewer people and still probably get close to what you were making. And most importantly, youâ€™ll burn out less.

### Discussion 599: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-12-17 19:36:31 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation
**Engagement:** 4 reactions, 30 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1924779388293284/

**Original Post:**
Has anyone gone from cash-based to in-network? I love my clinic and what we doâ€¦ but since I hired another therapist I canâ€™t get enough clientele to make overhead. But then if I switch I feel like Iâ€™m going to end  up like every other mill in my town and I refuse to do that.  But I know others in here do insuranceâ€¦. I saw my bosses in my old jobs rolling in dough while I was barely make ends meetâ€¦. How does insurance reimburse these days?  I have someone trying to convince me to be a multi-specialty clinic because it reimburses moreâ€¦ is that true? Has anyone done this?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I see this a lot, so Iâ€™ll be direct but hopefully helpful.

Most of the time the issue isnâ€™t cash vs insurance. Itâ€™s that cash practices expect being cash + good clinical care to magically solve hiring and filling schedules. That works when youâ€™re solo. It breaks the second you hire.

When you were alone, you had low overhead and lots of time. You could network, run workshops, meet people, hustle. Your hire is not going to do that at the same level, and they shouldnâ€™t be expected to. At that point, you need real systems.

Cash pay clinics that scale well all have a few things in place:
â€¢ Strong sales skills from the first phone call through the eval
â€¢ Clear package presentation (you have to sell packages)
â€¢ Continuity options so people donâ€™t disappear once pain improves
â€¢ An intentional marketing channel that doesnâ€™t rely on the ownerâ€™s time

On the insurance side, one thing I saw in the comments stood out. If BCBS reimburses better than your cash rates, thatâ€™s a pricing issue. Your cash rates are too low.

I totally get wanting to help more people, but once you charge anything above $0, youâ€™re already excluding someone. So you might as well price in a way that lets you run a sustainable business, pay staff well, and not burn out. Donâ€™t pick prices everyone can afford. Pick prices that support the business and the life you want.

Multi-specialty can reimburse more, but it also adds complexity and doesnâ€™t fix weak sales or marketing. Plenty of multi-specialty clinics still struggle for the same reasons.

Before jumping in-network, Iâ€™d fix sales, marketing, packaging, and pricing first. Cash pay can work very well, but only when itâ€™s run intentionally.

> **Response 2:** in what part of the country are you located?
In network benefits (BCBS) vary a lot depending on location.

### Discussion 603: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-06-13 22:24:10 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 4 reactions, 30 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/988139065290659/

**Original Post:**
Where does medicare draw the line of 'medically necessary' (I know I'm not the first one to ask this....just frustrated again)?  Say we have someone who can perform their daily functions with no restrictions (but maybe some mild discomfort/pain), however their main complaint is that  they are limited & painful in their ability to go hiking and play pickleball.  Would a wellness plan, with a treatment focus around making hiking & pickleball easier for them to participate in,  even if it entailed some manual therapy skills, be allowed under a cash-pay arrangement?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Donâ€™t confuse services covered under the Medicare benefit with medical necessity. 

Medical necessity is just one part of the requirements for covered services. 

Reasonable is another part. 

Standard of care is another part. 

This is a balancing act for sure. As Nancy mentioned, you are the therapist and make your determination based on the initial evaluation and findings. 

After that you develop your treatment plan and based on published guidelines you make a determination of what YOU believe falls within the coverage guidelines. 

You may charge cash for non-covered services and seek reimbursement for covered services. 

But reimbursement is always conditional. 

Ultimately you are not the one paying the bill nor is your patient. So Medicare would make the final determination if it ever came to that under review. 

And when Medicare makes that determination the Medicare rep will look at published guidelines and your documentation. 

I would say by far most of what I see in small, private practice outpatient therapy is largely non-covered services. But therapists are so desperate to help their patients they are willing to assume the financial liability associated with over utilization of services. Or they just donâ€™t understand the intent of Medicare coverage.

> **Response 2:** Sounds a lot more like a cash pay service. Unfortunately Medicare isnâ€™t concerned about someoneâ€™s ability to play pickle ballâ€¦ regardless of how important it is to the client

The old me would operate in fear and say not to hire her because she might hurt your business later... However, the new me who's been through this before both positively and negatively would advise this: 
IF she truly fits your mission, your culture, and can help you grow your business now, hire her. Mentor her as an entrepreneur. Teach her business on purpose. If she offers a specialty that you don't have currently, let her bring it to your clinic and build rapport with the community. 
If or when she leaves eventually, help her be successful and she'll do the same for you in return. Think of this as a partnership opportunity instead of a competition. Maintain her respect for you and when she leaves, that respect will remain and she may refer to you for people who don't fit her mold. Anyone who leaves with her is not your ideal client anyway. 

I actually developed a Direct Pay Mentorship Program with the intention of bringing in staff to build my practice, mentoring/training them to run their own practice, and then I offer an opportunity to stay or to leave to start their own. They may stay after seeing what running a business actually "costs" in time, money, and sacrifice.
I live in rural Appalachia... We don't have a high population or a great socioeconomic status, but there are still plenty of clients to go around. When you are mentoring someone who is driven, it helps BOTH of you. They will generate referrals for you while they are with you because they desire to be successful. They will push your business forward and make you better if they are the right fit... And you have ensured that the community has options for great care, whether it's you or not. 
At the end of the day, she may stay or she may go, but you can make it a positive experience for both of you if you approach it from a different perspective... 
I hope this helps!

> **Response 2:** They told you up front.Good sign of integrity. A shady person looking to snatch business likely would not have.

I would hire and maintain good communication along the way. When/if she wants to break away from you and do her own thing make sure there is a mutual understanding of expectations.

The reality is some people will follow her even without her solicitation. Thatâ€™s showbiz.

Weâ€™re in the people business, you build relationships, provide care for people, and people build bonds with providers/patients they spend time with. These bonds will cross company lines, and thatâ€™s ok.

Plenty of business to be had.

### Discussion 646: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT]

**Engagement:** 52 reactions, 5 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1038003773637521/

**Original Post:**
Have you ever been worried you'll hire and train someone only for them to leave, take your clients, and leave your business hurting? 

This is a fear I hear from our clients all the time and one I've felt before. 

The reality? 

VERY few people actually WANT to be business owners. This is a hard for me to say as a coach who helps people start businesses but the reality is that most people don't want that life. They don't want the risk they just want to be able to achieve something through their career and they feel that the only way to accomplish that is by being the business owner. 

What does this mean? 

If you can find and hire someone and give them what they're actually looking for (respect, autonomy, flexibility, financial upside, etc) and they see that they can do that WHILE working for someone I can almost guarantee they won't leave. 

People don't leave to start businesses because they want to be business owners, they leave because they feel like that's their only hope to achieve  what they're looking for. Don't give them another experience to solidify that belief and they'll reward you by sticking around.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** If you hire an exceptional PT, (the ones whose schedules are in high demamd) and you really want them to stick around, offer a path to part ownership of the practice.  At some point, they themselves will want to become uncaged.  This is how a lot of Attorney and Medical practices operate.

> **Response 2:** No. I donâ€™t hire anyone that crazy.

**Original Post:**
I need help! I was seeing a patient with Luna (outpatient at home) and patient was in the process of having Luna become an official provider with her Mass Mutual long term care insurance. She was not using Medicare whatsoever. She was self pay with Luna and Mass Mutual after 90 days would begin to reimburse her. Long story short, the patient and her husband became so irritated with the process (Luna and MM) that they have decided to hire me (cash based) to see her. 

If they do clear me as a provider, I am wanting to make sure 1. Mass Mutual understands that I am mobile outpatient and not home health. 2. If she was paying Luna self pay at $125, is it totally off to pay me cash?

After 90 days of care (she started with home health then moved on to outpatient) they will reimburse her services once they get the invoice. I left the clinic to not have to deal with insurance. Iâ€™m venting and asking for opinions on this, whether I should take her or not. She would pay me and I would provide an invoice just like Luna would have done for her. 

Hope this makes sense! Thoughts?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Besides the Medicare issue, I had a similar patient who wanted me to work with her when I wasnâ€™t established. I gave her receipts. But then she wanted to submit all the receipts to her long-term care and get reimbursed. The long-term care insurance wanted full codes, and Proof of billing that Medicare rejected it before paying for it. I would just make sure that sheâ€™s not using your bills to get paid back because then it opens up a can of worms. ï¿¼

> **Response 2:** Tricky situation. Typically the purpose of a LTC plan is to cover costs for the insured if they lose the ability or need significant help with at least 2 of 6 functional tasks: bathing, eating, dressing, toileting, bed transfers, and chair transfers. If her home health discharge OASIS paperwork showed that she was independent with these, Mass Mutual may have a case not to pay them. You would essentially have to show that she is restricted with at least 2 of these.

Since she still has Medicare, there still may be a case from a CMS federal level that she canâ€™t pay you cash if you/the patient are trying to  make a case that her treatment is medically necessary (because she has functional limitations that need treatment) 

I personally wouldnâ€™t take them as cash pay and would have them continue to go through Luna and/or use Medicare part B insurance. If she needs services like dry needling or other skills that are helpful and not covered by Medicare, I would invoice them for that and they can submit those services to Mass Mutual. They may still be eligible for some reimbursement and you wouldnâ€™t be caught in a battle between CMS and their private LTC policy

> **Response 1:** Some people need to take responsibility for their own issues.  I NEVER got paid for documentation.   Sounds like they need to grow up , become accountable.  And not get paid until their notes are done properly.

> **Response 2:** the safe approach is to handle performance issues in writing and follow a consistent process so it doesnâ€™t look retaliatory or arbitrary. Hereâ€™s what that normally looks like:
 1. Document clearly â€“ each time something happens, note the date, what occurred, and what policy or expectation wasnâ€™t met. Stick to facts: actions, deadlines missed, or behaviors observed.
 2. Meet and warn â€“ after one or two incidents, have a conversation and summarize it in writing (â€œverbal warning issued on X dateâ€).
 3. Written warning â€“ if it happens again, issue a formal notice describing the problem, the expected correction, and the possible consequences of continued issues. Have the employee sign acknowledgment (not agreement).
 4. Final warning / performance plan â€“ outline a short period to improve (usually 30 days) with measurable goals.
 5. Termination â€“ if thereâ€™s no improvement after documented warnings, you can end employment. Keep all documentation and communicate the decision succinctly and respectfully.

Be sure youâ€™re following:
 â€¢ State and federal labor laws (e.g., anti-discrimination and retaliation protections).
 â€¢ Your own written policiesâ€”consistency is key to legal defensibility.
 â€¢ HR or legal counsel advice if you have it, especially before final termination.

Why do people agree to pay cash to CAM specialists (Massage Therapists, Acupuncturists, Chiros, Personal Trainers) and Nutritionists and psychiatrists in Psychotherapists, yet fully expect insurance-based PT?

I think that the answer is somewhere in the following: 

PT as profession had a long journey to become recognized as a medical/healthcare field. Attaining medical recognition was a win and a loss. 

Today, two dfferent models of operation exist: 

Chiro + Personal Training + Massage = Wellness ~> Luxury: cash

PT = medical = necessity: insurance

Do we as PTs want to be associated with one or the other?

The answer is neither and both.
We need to carve a new model. And carving something new isâ€¦ hard.

Maybe the answer is to change the Wellness to Wellbeing in branding? Or Wellbeing and Whole Health?

Like .. â€œWellbeing in Function and Whole in Health PT?â€

Dunno.

I am in the very beginning of thinking about my own practice, associated with an unexpected but a welcome move. 

I will be planning and carving, drafting and re-writing things. 

One thing that I will be doing from the very start is to brand my practice as the place where clients start to feel better about themselves and about the things they do for the living, for recreation, for fun and - for functional mobility. 

Because the whip of insurance-based PT is the mere functional gain. Our society insurance-based model is to pay for the person not to die, the rest is secondary.

I want people to be more than functional.  Beyond functional. 

Likeâ€¦ hurt by personal training -> seek Beyond Functional PT to return to sport.
â€¦ not responding to acupuncture 
-> seek Beyond Functional PT to relieve pain.

Not long time ago Massage Therapists started being recognized as professionals and not a subsidy of sex work industry.  Just 15 years ago I was asked by a client in a well-respected upscale spa if we do happy ending (I came to PT from being a LMT first). 

Somehow Massage Therapists are not recognized by Insurance as providers of medically necessary therapy (even though regular therapeutic massage greatly relives stress on par with Psychotherapy covered by insurance). 

We as a whole profession need a break from medical necessity equating negligent pay.  

And just maybe APTA need to step up too. But itâ€™s a subject for the next rant.

Thanks for your attention.

### Discussion 701: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-03-20 17:38:01 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 3 reactions, 28 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1434275207343707/

**Original Post:**
Best tips and tricks to avoid burnout?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I just started following Brene Browns stuff and its amazing!

> **Response 2:** Take time to identify your values. (There are some good worksheets available to help with this process.) Then, ask yourself if how you're living is lining up with those.

Take time to learn about how you show up best at work, and do more of that. I love the Working Genius model for this. The assessment is about $20 I think, and well worth it. There is also a podcast by the same name that is honestly an amazing listen.

Take time to figure out the types of things that recharge you. MAKE TIME to do those things.

Take time to listen to your body. Learn how it tells you that you're stressed. And work with a counselor if possible to learn how to cope with the inevitable stress of life.

Give yourself permission to make beneficial changes.

If at all possible, work with a counselor.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** YES - talk now. Just know that plans may change. But, have an idea in your head of how things may/may not play out.

Demonstrating kindness, empathy, or compassion when communicating is not a sign of weakness. **You can be a strong leader while still being kind.

Obviously, when an employee takes advantage of the employerâ€™s kindness or empathy, that is an issue. The employer must take action to ensure it doesnâ€™t happen more than once. 

Giving each employee the benefit of the doubt, in the beginning, is the best approach, in my opinion. 

Be direct and honest with her about YOUR needs as an employer/business owner, while simultaneously demonstrating understanding for her situation. 

Any reasonable person understands you need to ensure you have a physical PT in the clinic to treat clients until she returns. 

Let us know how the talk goes - interested to hear how it plays out!

> **Response 2:** First things firstâ€¦ way to go offering some paid maternity leave. That is a huge blessing for families!
