### Discussion 711: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-03-06 19:50:49 | **Topic:** 03-insurance-billing-reimbursement
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 28 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1425722781532283/

**Original Post:**
How do you educate patients about the difference between Medicare and Medicare replacement plans?  I take medicare, and patients keep saying they have medicare, and I get them all signed up, and then find out it's replacement, add they don't understand why they would have to pay.  ðŸ˜¬

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** They should have read the book they're given each year to explain how their health services are billed. ðŸ˜‘  If in person, ask to see their cards first. If not, have them email a copy. You need that to verify coverage anyway. Tell them up front you don't take Medicare Advantage plans. If they are not paying anything extra each month than their $174.90 that is usually subtracted from their Social Security payments, they probably have an Advantage plan. Although some Advantage plans have extra premiums as well. Sounds like their Insurance agent didn't educate them well. It's the job of the agent to make sure they understand their coverage. I would direct them back to their agent if you don't want to spend the time. 

Traditional Medicare is quite costly. I remember my mom paying up to $454 a month over her base premium (now $174.90). And she wasn't really ill until her last year alive. Only hospitalized for 2 TIAs and having 3 children. You are going to see more and more taking Advantage plans. They have a max out of pocket limit that lowers the financial risk. If you are not an ill person, Advantage plans make sense. Plus you get dental and vision benefits, and other perks. Otherwise you are paying close to $600 a month for Insurance you may or may not use

> **Response 2:** I ask for their cards before, check benefits. If they have Advantage I explain they chose to give up their Medicare benefits to an insurance company who now â€œmanagesâ€ their health care like any other insurance company. I then refer them to another PT clinic that may take their insurance. The Advantage plans are absolutely awful and predatory and should be illegal the way they prey on our elders.

Hey all. I have a severe thoracic outlet case who is awaiting thoracic surgeon appointment. Long hx of pain and has been in and out of PT for 2 years with some relief but nothing long lasting. It appears to be true vascular compression. I am trying to alleviate some of her symptoms leading up to the appointment. Are there any unique go to techniques you all have found helpful in these cases? TIA!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Muscle energy technique and even SCS have powerful techniques for  TOS..

> **Response 2:** Check for hypermobility at the shoulder as well. My best friend from PT school had an unrelenting case of thoracic outlet and also scores a 7-8 on the Beighton scale (I forget her exact score). Whenever she would carry things, the traction on her shoulder was contributing significantly to her TOS. She was able to largely resolve her symptoms with a lot of work on shoulder stabilization. She also did a lot of work to improve her awareness so she could rely more on active vs passive support of the shoulder, especially with lifting/carrying.

**Original Post:**
ISOLATION: The second great killer of your business 

You weren't meant to do THIS alone and by "THIS" I don't just mean business. 

Scenario 1: I hate when people outside a select few friends ask me how business is going. It doesn't seem fair to have to communicate something as complicated as an entrepreneur's emotions. It's great, it's terrible, it's ok, it's frustrating, it's exhilarating, it's everything at the same time. So most of the time people ask I simply say "it's going well" and leave it at that. 

The problem with this? It puts you on an island feeling that no one can possibly understand or know what you're going through. 

Scenario 2: there's something that's been engrained in you from your childhood- using other people to help you is cheating, you need to do it on your own, group projects are awful, and if you collaborate with someone it cheapens what you're accomplishing. 

All of these things have gone through my head from time to time. I want to prove to everyone that I can do it on my own and don't need to rely on support or help from outsiders. "I didn't borrow money from a wealthy family member to get started." "I'm the reason people are coming to my practice." "I'm going to see how far I can get it on my own before asking for help." 

Phrases like this are so prevalent in our culture. 

Both of these scenarios create a pattern of isolation that make us susceptible to a number of problems. We burn out because we can't sustain the level of energy we're putting in. We quit because there's no accountability to push through challenges. We feel depressed because we're alone. 

At the very least you don't need to do this alone but the honest truth is that doing this alone is irresponsible. Don't let yourself become susceptible to isolation. Surround yourself with community to support you and allow you to have the greatest opportunity to have true success.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 2:** Perfect timing for this!  Ty! 
Iâ€™m a bit tired of the island lately â¤ï¸

Need some thoughts on an opportunity. I currently treat both MCR and cash pts with my fully mobile practice . I charge $150/visit. I was approached by a local country club with a large membership. They would like me to treat their members at the club. They would take 20% of monies. I told them $175/ visit (the idea is to recoup the 20%).  I would be there for maybe 4-5 hrs at a clip. Am I being greedy to ask for the $175/visit? Thoughts on $175 for eval and then $150 return visits? Thanks, everyone!!!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Someone in a pelvic floor group I follow put it this way: â€œI just paid $200 to have a clown at my kids bday party for an hourâ€. Consider that when setting your rates.

> **Response 2:** Iâ€™ve actually have done this in the past. Worked well but the must earn their 20% , I believe it was 20% for me as well 

1. You cannot treat Medicare there unless you get that site blessed by Medicare 
2. The country club better have all the equipment you need to effectively do your job 
3. The country club likely will be handling all the money up front ie drawing from their members accounts on a monthly basis   So you need to ensure your books are accurate so they pay you correctly 
4. The country club should assist you on scheduling their members with their front desk/spa staff. 
5. They should also market on your behalf as 20% of 10 clients vs 100 clients is much more advantageous to them. 
6 your rates seem low but all of that is area dependent, and what you are comfortable charging. We aee 275 eval 175 follow up 350 ultrasound diagnostics. Commonly an eval will pull in $625 in an hour  and the members love it.

I think I can cover the lower end of the monthly rent with one person's 10-session package BUT I'm worried about "will I have time for myself?", "will seeing 10 patients/week be too overwhelming?", "what if I can't even get people to buy in my services and now I have to cough up my own money to pay the rent" if I end up going this route. I eventually declined the offer for the moment but felt this might be a great opportunity.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** $1000/month for a 1000 Sq ft gym seems excessive. See if they are willing to give you a per hour rate. I pay $25/hour where I do side stuff. Normally only a few patients per week.
A per month rate that high would only make sense if you are there full time.

> **Response 2:** At first glance that sounds too high of rent for so a side hustle. If they really wanted you, I would try to negotiate a percentage of your billed amount.

I have a quick question. One of my patients approach me and asked me to provide private PT @ home in NYC after he run out of his Medicare B service.
 
Whatâ€™s the legal and ethical way or procedure to start cash base (private pay)physical therapy services at home for Medicare B patients in NY after they already reach their market cap and wanted PT via private pay (out of pocket) . 

Can anyone clear my following doubts ..

1. Can I legally work with Med B as cash pay(out of pocket)..?

2. I have to get ABN form signed before I start as private pay for med B home care patient  ..!? Right

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Firstly there is no cap. Medicare covers medically necessary skilled therapy services.  You can charge cash for services that are not covered by Medicare or do not meet the above criteria. If it is something that Medicare would normally cover but would not be covered in this case you would complete an ABN with the client prior to beginning services. For services Medicare would not normally cover e.g. dry needling or fitness program you would use your usual waiver. If it is skilled therapy that meets that criteria then it must be billed to Medicare. Therapists are not allowed to opt out and there is a mandatory claims submission requirement.

### Discussion 873: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-07-23 14:35:41 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 4 reactions, 23 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1516568605781033/

**Original Post:**
This seems so basic, but how do you actually drop off marketing materials to referring clinicians/mds?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Something off beat or off the wall like a shock and awe package.
Having written a book on your expertise works well, because it takes up physical space on their desk or shelf, but stays subconsciously in the mind. 
Mail a package of peanuts directly to the doctor with a flyer saying â€œYouâ€™d be nuts not to work with usâ€
A rubber foot saying â€œIâ€™ve done the hard work for you and got my foot in the doorâ€¦now hereâ€™s how we can work with each other to benefit our patientsâ€
If you have a local podcast, getting them on as a guest then opening the 2 way street is a good one.

> **Response 2:** Here's my process (I'll probably get a million comments saying I'm doing it wrong but....). When I go in, I only bring one form of marketing materials, letter, brochure, card, so I have excuses to come back and drop off more. When I go in, I ask the front desk person their name and if I can drop off materials for the doctor (s). Always respect their level of busy-ness. If they have time for small chitter-chatter while I get out the materials, then that's fine. As soon as I leave the office, I write down the name of the front desk person and any little details they said (going on vacation soon, only work in the mornings, etc). I then put in my calendar when I'll be coming back to drop off more info. On the return visit, I say hello to the front desk person by name and say something about our last conversation (how was your vacation? I came in the morning because I knew you'd be here....) While dropping off different marketing materials from the last time, I try to get some Intel from the front desk (would I be able to schedule a meeting with the doc? How does your office handle PT referrals? Etc). It's a snowball process of getting the trust of the front desk, the gatekeepers. So you can get in to see the MDs face to face.

### Discussion 980: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-05-19 19:01:00 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 33 reactions, 7 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/970627387041827/

**Original Post:**
Vulnerability. 

I share some of my personal struggles because it's important for people here to see a couple different things. 

1.  It's possible to LOVE life and still have struggles. I love what I get to do, I love who I get to work with, I'm proud of what I've accomplished and live an amazing life. I also struggle with doubts, mindset and mental health issues, and have days that are hard. This is life and even though it seems like people who are successful never have a bad day, thats BS. 
1. It's ok for a leader to show vulnerability. In fact, it's essential. I can't do things on my own. I need others to help me. I need to recognize that despite my best efforts I'll fall short unless surrounded by others to help support me. There's a misconception that building a business on your own is the "courageous" way of doing it. We live in a society where individual work is celebrated and using a team or others to support you is often seen as "cheating" (see school as an example). Trying to do things on your own will get you limited results and the primary reason that people do things on their own is PRIDE. They don't want to show vulnerability because of their pride so they do things on their own and never admit they need help. So by showing my vulnerability I hope to help people see that the smart way, the brave way, the courageous way of doing things is to recognize limitations and ask for help.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** This is exactly what I have found out and am taking action on with myself and my team. Thank you for sharing since this resonates with me so much!

> **Response 2:** This resonates with me so much! Probably one of the biggest lessons I have been learning since starting my practice.

> **Response 1:** If they are treating in a dance studio, it's unlikely they will be seeing Medicare, so that piece might be a moot point. **Original Post:**
What is the logistics of starting a Home Health Company?  We are an outpatient neuro clinic and was wondering how feasible is it to start a home health company that is neuro specific? ðŸ˜

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** We have 7 outpatient physical therapy clinics. We opened a home health agency 14 years ago too. 

We are independent in both and have so many experienced clinicians.  I am the director of therapy for the outpatient and Administrator for the home health company.  

Itâ€™s a lot harder to open the home health company.  You have to so much money in an account to show and basically treat the first 10 Medicare patients for free (it was 14 years ago). A lot more regulations for licensing.  Must have a Director of Nursing and the policies and procedures are totally different.  I been through 4 state surveys for both.  Nothing is the same except the emergency preparedness plan we have to maintain for both. We have two 
separate companies and two separate EMRS and billing.  

I feel home health is not patient generated and driven only by discharge planners.  Iâ€™m not sure how much a specialist would do as visits could be limited.  People generally do not have freedom of choice.  The hospitals dictate agencies then if they go to a SNF, they tend to dictate who is picked.  

I personally feel the best way to be a specialist and be sought out is only through outpatient at home.  Not home health. If you want to get into home health , contract with a home health agency first.  

We have so many outpatient therapists that specialize that also do home health, and it does not generate additional business in home health. We are a top provider in outpatient in our area but it never has helped us in home health.

My wife worked in home health for years  and was a Parkinsonâ€™s specialist.  She left her home health company (different than the one Iâ€™m in charge of and it was owned by a hospital) and started a separate outpatient at home business.  She does so much more business as an outpatient provider using her specialty.  

So, basically I have seen outpatient, outpatient at home, and home health through 3 different companies.

Winning formula = contract yourself out to home health agency, see patients for the plan of care. Once the agency discharges, go in as outpatient provider with through indoor self pay. Agencies are limiting home-health visits and patients have such a need after discharge.

> **Response 2:** I don't think neuro patients would be as profitable because they will require a lot more intensity of care, more visits and likely more disciplines involved. Majority of the time our neuro patients were getting PT, OT, ST, MSW, nursing, and HHA.

For my mobile providers: do you find yourself constantly messing with your schedule to try and keep drives close together as possible, then you DC someone and get someone new who now lived 20 mins the other way and youâ€™re shuffling things all over (and also feel bad for switching current patientâ€™s times)

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Definitely some schedule management. I have 2 different zones, one area M/W, then second area Tues/Thursday that are reasonably close to each other. I do my best to predict, but occasionally ask a patient to slide up or down to avoid zig zagging around town...but I always look a week ahead to prep for that. There are patients that have standing times too. Most are reasonable! I've found I'm able to route decently to be timely, but I do call if I'm more than 5 minutes off.

> **Response 2:** I group and schedule my patients by geographic location. I will even explain this to them during the scheduling process so they understand and none of them have complained at all about it. 

If you think about when you go to the doctor, you just have to take whatever is available. If a patient really wants the service it's not going to make or break you unless of course you only have  an 8:00 a.m. or a 5:00 p.m. or something like that. 

Even with the best laid intentions I have had patients who are 5 minutes away from each other and one has a last-minute doctor appointment and I can't group them together which is frustrating. But it definitely gets easier when you set your boundaries!   

And to make things easier I actually do my schedule only one week at a time. That way I don't waste time moving things around.  Pretty much at the end of their last visit of the week I then go over the schedule for the following week and I put them on. I try to keep their times pretty consistent, just to make scheduling easier.  And I don't allow them to schedule, since I need full control of the calendar based on the geography. ðŸ˜

I actually have two patients right now who live in a neighborhood 30-35 minutes away. That is very far for me but they are both cash pay patients. But I made it very clear to them that because of the distance I have to see both of them on the same day. And they both are fine with it!

If you're making good money, switching your LLC to an S-Corp can also save on taxes. Def worth talking to a tax pro who gets the mobile therapy world!

### Discussion 1088: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-12-12 16:56:16 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 7 reactions, 18 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1371764746928087/

**Original Post:**
Does anyone have recommendations/advice on how to do better marketing? Specifically via social media/Instagram to gain folllowers?  I now have online fitness programs up on Everfit app and trying to find ideas on how to better market the programs and gain clients.  Marketing to my womens mountain bike club of 3,500+ ladies hasnâ€™t been enough so far.  ðŸ˜’

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Be consistent, pool your audience to know what they want to know, create content around what they want to know and not what you think they want to know, be consistent and post daily.

> **Response 2:** Donâ€™t overcomplicate it. Just provide value. Post simple videos or text posts answering a common question or issue your clients run into. Do NOT get caught into the trap of trying over explain yourself in your caption (we all do it). Because then it will take you like 45 minutes to make 1 post. Keep things as simple as you can and try to make each post just 1 main thing you are trying to get across. Donâ€™t worry about editing posts or anything. Just post. Show your personality (people work with people they like). See what works and what doesnâ€™t. Go from there. 

Why would somebody want your program? What are they going to get out of it? And I donâ€™t mean â€œget stronger, more fit, etc etcâ€ because every program ever says that. What actual problem will your program help solve for mountain bikers? What are the things people complain about most often? Stay on the bike longer? No longer need long rest breaks once you get to the top? 

Donâ€™t try to just post stuff on the mountain biking group to market, just be in there a lot and answer questions and show them you are knowledgeable and eventually people will reach out to you. 

Think of social media marketing as farming. Just keep planting seeds, and then eventually youâ€™ll be able to harvest them.

Hey guys! Quick question. Is emailing my previous patients from my old corporate job about my new cash paying PT business unethical or a hippa violation? I have about 8 to 10 patients that I happen to have their email addresses from some internal reviews they posted within the company. They posted about me and I wasnâ€™t sure how to proceed because I had a good relationship with them and I would like to let them know where I am now, but I also donâ€™t want to violate anything by sending them an email. Please advise ðŸ˜Š

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I would not. It could be construed as a HIPAA violation as to how you got their personal information outside of work

> **Response 2:** It could be viewed as â€œunethicalâ€ from a business perspective and your former employer could take legal action for â€œpoachingâ€ and soliciting their patients  even if you directly were treating them  Technically and legally it is their patients - not yours. This does not include if you also signed any NDA ,  Non-compete is the least of your worries and does not really apply here depending on your state laws. 

It does violate certain HIPAA practice standards since you should not even have their email addresses those should have been discarded upon leaving your former employer - much less attempt to contact them.

There is â€œfreedom of choiceâ€ so if the patients do not want to continue with their current provider and decide to seek you out on their own without being influenced from outside sources, then there is nothing your employer can do and your golden.

**Original Post:**
For all the solo mobile practices out there, how do you handle time out of the office greater than a week? Iâ€™m going to be out of the area for 2 weeks. Do you bring in another PT to help out as an independent contractor? Do your clients simply wait until you return? Would love to hear what you all do.  Thanks!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** We left and closed the clinic for 3 weeks last year, no issues. We made sure patients had extensive HEP activities and stressed compliance. **Original Post:**
There are two ditches on both sides of the road to avoid when growing your business:

Left ditch - "I can figure it out on my own." That is fueled by pride/ego and can get us in trouble. It's always healthiest to stay open to learning at all times. 

Right ditch - Over-consuming all information that you can get your hands on. Many people read books and absorb information that isn't helpful in the stage of business they are in, and steers them away from implementation of the right things. 

The heart of this post comes from hearing many people tell me that they have pre-ordered Alex Hormozi's $100M Leads. Every book he puts out is fantastic, no doubt...BUT here is the question I ask each time: Is that what you NEED to be reading to get you to your next level of growth?

If not, be disciplined enough to pick up the RIGHT book.
So, why is this important?

Because I've literally seen practice owners who REALLY just need to hire another PT, pick up a book like that and get side tracked for MONTHS because they are trying to implement the wrong thing.

That book at the RIGHT time for the RIGHT business, Im sure will be exceptional, but really the PT in the example above just needs to focus on hiring, and learning how to do so properly.

Stay on the road at all costs! Don't get distracted and veer yourself off the road only to realize months later how far you have gone off the road. 

You can do this! This is just my reminder to stay focused and avoid the two ditches.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Comparison is how Satan works in businessâ€¦especially for believers. He knows we naturally have desires to have more or do more. When we think we need more or something different comparison starts to run our business and gets us off track

> **Response 2:** Great reminder!!!ðŸ’ªðŸ¼ðŸ¥°

Generally when I drop that first line and leave it, theyâ€™ll have some questions that will demonstrate sticking points if they have any. Ultimately most are just asking that because they think thatâ€™s how youâ€™re supposed to shop for healthcare, not because theyâ€™re sold on going in network. I own an in home personal training business for seniors in which I provide therapy inspired exercises (private pay). Iâ€™m ready to hire and need any help/advice I can get on hiring a 1099 employee. **Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Before you move ahead, please understand that a '1099' is a form you issue to any contractor for whom you paid more than $600/year so they can report it on their taxes. (This law is if you're in the USA)

If you're looking for an employee, it's not the same as a '1099'.

By the sounds of what you're looking to do, you probably cannot have independent contractors because the workers will be an integral part of your business.

Here's a blog post that might help understand about the difference between ICs and employees. 

(Ask me how I know!)ðŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸

https://www.irenediamond.com/are-you-an-really-ic-or-employee

> **Response 2:** As a current 1099 employee, I wouldnâ€™t sign anything with a non compete. My feeling as an independent contractor is I should be able to work for whoever, whenever I want. If you want me to sign a non compete than make me a W2 employee so I donâ€™t get killed in taxes and give me benefits.

### Discussion 1169: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-01-28 17:23:58 | **Topic:** 07-clinical-practice-specialties
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 20 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1401776953926866/

**Original Post:**
This company near me offers Pelvic Floor Therapy. They are Naturopathic Doctors, all fine, but I noticed this on their website - are they able to bill this under PT??? That doesn't seem right.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** They can see the patient for pelvic therapyas a cash patient.  but it would be fraud to bill under Physical therapy and use the patients insurance benefits under PT if they are not a licensed PT

> **Response 2:** I do not know the answer to your question. Iâ€™m learning this too. But I do know that we as a physical therapy profession do not â€œownâ€ CPT codes, they are universally used in the medical field and selected by a provider and should only be utilized within a scope of practice. So therapeutic exercise can be used for different professions than just physical therapist. So physicians can bill 97110 and they would put their modifier instead of ours(GP). Also, the Herman and Wallace Institute allows a wide array of providers to take their courses, including Naturopathic Doctors. Many other pelvic floor courses can be taken by others. I know a personal trainer that calls her self a pelvic floor therapy specialist and states she has multiple pelvic floor certifications. So if it is the scope of treatment for Natropathic Doctors to perform and they have the skill set then I suspect they could bill. I see many different professions calling themselves pelvic floor specialists from holistic doctors to nurse midwives to personal trainers. Also, they are typically skillful with the wording calling it pelvic floor therapy instead of pelvic floor physical therapy.

### Discussion 1191: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT]

Whatâ€™s the going rate for cash based pelvic PT in Los Angeles? Someone I know is being charged $250 per visit. Is that reasonable?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** The only person who can deem it reasonable or not is the patient/client. Does he/she feel that what they are receiving is worth the rate they're paying? Because we all value things differently, and see that value from different points of view.

My rates are well above the rates of anyone else in my area. But every one of my clients are convinced that what they receive is well worth every penny they spent. Does the fact that my rates are higher than anyone else around me mean that my rates are unreasonable? People who choose not to work with me probably think so. People who do choose to work with me often feel I am undervaluing my services. The eye of the beholder is a powerful thing.

> **Response 2:** Thatâ€™s within average rates for pelvic PTs in this area. But I also think this post has an undertone of judgment about someone elseâ€™s rates. As Joe said above, the only person who can deem it reasonable is the patient/client. If they feel the service is valuable at that rate, they will pay it. If they donâ€™t, they wonâ€™t. Thereâ€™s room in the market for different levels of service priced at different rates.

### Discussion 1228: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-09-30 18:37:31 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 19 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1565642240873669/

**Original Post:**
Hi y'all! I'm in need of a recommendation! I treat competitive swimmers. A particular female swimmer of mine (high school aged) presented with (bil) shoulder pain in the middle of the summer. She has done 9 PT appts with me (1x/week). Per her words, she no longer has pain but does have a lingering soreness in the anterior shoulders during and after practice. The soreness is not severe enough to have her get out of the water. 

She has horrible shoulder posture and also has a larger chest. Her mother informed me that she has had horrible posture for years (her mother is reportedly always on her case about her posture). I wholeheartedly believe her continued soreness is a result of her posture.

Her mother has asked for a recommendation on a posture bra. I know nothing about posture bras except for what I found during a quick google search. Seems they are built with a mechanism similar to the posture braces that promote scapular retraction. I'm not fond of these braces long-term. I would rather see her continue to strengthen her periscapular muscles and improve her shoulder/scapular stability.

BUT...would a posture bra be a good short-term solution? Can anyone provide any more insight than what you can find googling and/or particular brands recommendations?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Instead of putting a growing adult into some sort of â€œposture braâ€ you should educate her mother that there is very little research that supports â€œperfect postureâ€ and the reason for her pain is because the child is most likely from trying to maintain that posture that her mother expects. Allow the child to sit how they like and let their shoulders relax, I would be surprised if her pain still lingers after that adjustment.

> **Response 2:** As a large chested woman, Iâ€™d focus more on getting her in a correct sized bra. Posture bras do nothing. Instead, she needs to go to a bra fitting store, or Nordstrom. They need to be prepared to spend moneyâ€¦ good bras are not cheap. More than likely, sheâ€™s gone to target or Victorias Secret and is trying to fit herself in to the bras that are available. When she is in a bra that fits, the band should be quite snug. Thatâ€™s where the support comes from. Cup size and band size are inversely related, so if her band has been too big her cup has probably been too small. Once sheâ€™s in the right size bra, then work on posterior chain strengthening to take some of the load off the biceps and pecs.

**Original Post:**
Is anyone willing to share their single visit rate vs package rate and how they went about deciding if packages were a good idea?   Currently I donâ€™t offer packages but considering it as a way to offer a more affordable option to those who need it.   Thank you!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I did primarily packages for about a year and now have switched to $150/session. Honestly has just been better all around with everyone paying the same rate and losing less in discounts all over the place. I do offer paid in full options for anyone who wants nothing to do with Superbills/insurance and just wants to pay in full for 12 sessions. Those are 10% off but I rarely use those now

> **Response 2:** The rates people are sharing will fluctuate depending on location, specialty, and if mobile/concierge. Consider a sales tactic called price anchoring where you have a significantly higher single session rate and packages that seem like a great discount. This pushes people to get the package, which leads to more money upfront and commitment from the patient's end to complete the POC. Individual sessions can lead to drop off/no show when the patient stops seeing the value or if there isnt an immediate change

### Discussion 1295: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-12-09 17:14:41 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 4 reactions, 17 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1918533988917824/

**Original Post:**
Iâ€™ve been connecting with a local DPC/concierge doc, and we want to formally collaborate. Sheâ€™d like to be able to pipeline her patients to me, but include my service as part of the fee theyâ€™re already paying her (so not just a referral, and then they pay for my service). We are trying to figure out how to make this work so that I am also getting paid what I am due. Could this be as simple as the physician paying me out of petty cash from her practice when I see one of her clients, or do we need to go through credenting and billing as if a traditional clinic? Or something else?? Open to ideas â€¦ I have been totally solo an fully cash-based practice for several years, so this is new territory!!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I love that youâ€™re thinking through this before you jump in, because the way you structure it now is whatâ€™s going to make this collaboration actually work long term.

There are a few clean ways to look at it.

First option: treat it like youâ€™re getting free leads. If she wants to keep her pricing exactly the same and not rearrange anything, that can still work. The big thing is you cannot let people just show up at your door expecting free ongoing PT. You need a 15 minute phone call with them first so you can set expectations clearlyâ€¦
â€œHereâ€™s what the eval normally costs, hereâ€™s what this first session looks like inside your DPC membership, and hereâ€™s what people with your issue typically need in terms of sessions.â€
Basically give it the full discovery call feel so they understand where the free part ends and where your actual plan of care begins. That protects you and makes the whole thing way smoother.

Second option: if sheâ€™s planning to raise her prices, then your service can just be baked into that increase. It becomes a value add for her members and she stays whole financially. My guess is sheâ€™s probably not looking to raise prices, but itâ€™s still worth mentioning because itâ€™s the most straightforward version of the model.

Third option: she pays you directly per person she sends over. If you go this route, compare it to what youâ€™d normally spend on acquiring a patient. If youâ€™re running paid ads, depending on your city you might be paying anywhere from $80 to $150 just to get someone on a phone call. These arenâ€™t cold traffic leads though. These are warm, already-sold referrals coming from someone they trust. Thatâ€™s worth a lot. Your conversion rate on those will typically be double what you get from ads.

If you frame it that way, you can structure a win-win so every patient who needs PT goes straight to you as the default, not â€œone of several options.â€ She sells it as part of the experience. You take it from the first call onward.

So youâ€™ve got a few models here. Just make sure whatever you choose sets expectations properly and positions you as the consistent PT solution for her people. Thatâ€™s where this kind of relationship becomes genuinely fruitful instead of chaotic.

> **Response 2:** You have to be careful with these laws -the easiest way is to just accept referrals from the doc : 

Federal Anti-Kickback Statute (AKS): Prohibits knowingly offering, paying, soliciting, or receiving any remuneration (cash, gifts, discounts) to induce referrals for services paid by federal programs (Medicare/Medicaid).
Violations are felonies with severe penalties (prison, fines, exclusion from programs).
Stark Law (Physician Self-Referral Law): Prohibits physicians from referring patients for certain services (like lab work, PT, imaging) to entities they or their family have a financial relationship with (ownership or compensation), unless an exception applies.
State Laws: Many states (e.g., Texas) have independent anti-solicitation or anti-kickback laws that can be stricter.
Professional Ethics: The APA and other  organizations specify that payments should be for services rendered, not based on the referral.

**Original Post:**

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** As a physician, I would like a "Thanks for referring (patient name). She is progressing well and I plan to see her for another x weeks. She has a followup set up to see you after that. Please don't hesitate to call us you have any questions about her therapy."

As all healthcare providers, physicians are busy. I dont want to spend the time opening a card that just says thanks for the referral. What does help is someone saying you passed the ball, I've got it and I'm taking care of the patient. It also helps that it's noted the patient has a followup already and it's not asking the physician to look things up or set more things up. Hope that helps. If it's ok with HIPPA (I would think it is) it helps to include the name because there are certain patients that stick out to you and having that reassurance in a quick read is gold.

> **Response 2:** If possible, Iâ€™ll personally drop off the eval and offer an in-person thank you to any new MD referral sources, which removes any HIPPA issues. 
Also, I set up a weekly call in time w several of my main referral MDs, so I can give him/her a quick live update about their Ptâ€™s. They appreciate getting live feedback, so they can ask questions etc. This is especially true for those MDs who offer concierge cash based services; as they want to really be on top of their pts and want their pts to know their getting full personal service and care. This way, they tell the pt â€œI spoke to your PT, he said youâ€™re doing better etcâ€. Also, it helps me recapture lost/lazy pts, as the MD will call them to remind them to restart PT

### Discussion 1340: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-02-18 13:01:27 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 5 reactions, 16 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1669698203801405/

**Original Post:**
I'm a physical therapist looking to connect with others who have partnered with gyms. I'm interested in learning more about how these relationships work, especially in regards to using gym equipment and bringing in non-member clients.

Questions:

How do you typically structure your partnership with the gym?
Are you allowed to bring in clients who are not members? If so, are there any restrictions or limitations?
Do you have to prioritize the gym's members over your own clients?
What are the benefits and challenges of partnering with a gym?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I do not have a private practice but have been researching here and there for a few years. These are great questions, but unfortunately, the answer is not one-size-fits-all. In terms of amenities and business practices, things may differ between gyms, so itâ€™s essential to know what you want for both your patients and your business.

Not allowing non-members would be a major red flag. Everything else can and should be negotiated.

If they want member priority, this could be harmful for growth, but you can counter with offering designated member-only times, discounted member rates, asking for lower rent, or requesting marketing support.

There is so much ambiguity in this aspect that it will be beneficial to know where you will excel and where you may struggle, so that you ensure the partnership is mutually beneficial and unlikely to lead to future tension.

Protect your brand and your values (this is your motivation and drive), ensure a contract is formed (with plenty of reflection and revision), have an exit strategy in writing, and build in a re-negotiation date at a certain checkpoint.

As for structure, the most common that you will see are flat rate rent, percentage of revenue, or a hybrid. If you expect very fast growth, then a flat rate may be optimal. If you expect slow growth, a percentage of revenue may be better. A hybrid offers them a guarantee while giving you protection if growth is slow.

You could offer a revenue cap where you pay a percentage of revenue up to a certain threshold, followed by a reduction in percentage â€” possibly even to zero. Another option is a tiered split, where the percentage decreases as your revenue increases.

> **Response 2:** Depends on your agreement/contract with gym. I like percent per visit (can be anywhere 10-30% depending on how everything is set up) rather than flat fee, this gives the gym incentive to send people your way.

Hey Uncaged Community! Iâ€™m looking for the wisdom of the SPORTS/ORTHO/RUNNING EXPERTS in this group! I received this text from a friend who is a long-time runner, triathlete, and Physicianâ€™s Assistant. Any advice? Iâ€™d love to connect her with anyone who offers virtual services/consults/advice and can help! She is located in Virginia.

â€œIf itâ€™s okay, I was hoping to pick your brain a bit? (Before I panic).

I ran my first race since my stress fracture almost 2 weeks ago now (April 23rd- ðŸŽ‰) 9 months post stress fracture. I felt great, no pain, legs were just pretty sore the next day thanks to some tough hills.  

I got sick about mid week after my race, and still am currently sick (I believe theyâ€™ve lovingly called this runners flu)â€¦ I have been laid up since then feeling super run down and havenâ€™t been able to run or really workout- trying to be smart and listen to my body. 

Earlier this week, my ankle started really bothering me- just some deep achy/annoying painâ€¦ and worse at night. Which raised some flags for me. The weather has been yuck so I attributed it to that at first. But the rainy/storms have passed and Iâ€™m still having a constant nagging ache. Worse when Iâ€™m just sitting and still worse at night. 

Have you ever heard of illness triggering that same â€œflareâ€ of an old injury like weather does ? Or do you think it might be more cause for concern to check in/follow up on? 

It just doesnâ€™t make sense to me. I felt great during my race and over a week past that I felt good and then all of a sudden it starts giving me trouble when Iâ€™m not even exercisingâ€¦â€

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I agree that she should probably have it re-imaged to r/o stress fracture recurrence, but the fact that it is happening primarily when she is NWB and at the end of the day makes me think that there is also a possible referral from the spine or hip instead of pain from stress fracture. **Original Post:**
How do you guys hire/find new PT's? I live in a smaller town, close to a huge city, about an hour away. But If I could, I could hire 4-5 more PT's based on how busy we are. But It is so hard to find anyone right now. I've done job fairs but that's more long term Investing In hiring someone.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Do you take students?  That might be a nice way to train and recruit future therapists get awareness for your practice.

> **Response 2:** When recruiting therapists, no matter where, active recruiting is a must. 

So not just posting a job and hoping/waiting for applicants. Getting a licensure list from your state which usually will include emails (and hopefully phone numbers), emailing, texting, calling to those is the zip codes close to you. 

Posting on social media/linkedIn. 

Get in touch with the local PT schools in your area and try and connect with those last year PT students. 

Differentiating your job when you post it. Highlight the reasons someone would want to work for you. Also donâ€™t list every duty/the entire job description in the post. Itâ€™s not necessary and no one reads it. 

Itâ€™s so important to get back to applicants the same day and set up an interview asap. Then make a decision quickly.

**Original Post:**
Quick question for those who work with those who have become injured playing pickleball? I do work with older clients but am not familiar with the game of pickleball. I'm seeing several groin injuries and am curious what I can do to help these folks reduce the risk of this injury. I believe there is tightness in the adductors and IR of the hips but want to be sure I'm not missing something else.Thank you for any help.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** A big element I work on is footwork. Various foot work drills to help avoid the end ranges of motion during a game. 
â€¦
We canâ€™t change the 40 years of degeneration, but if we can help them move better within the a available range of motion maybe we can reduce the risk of injury.

> **Response 2:** I would say eccentric control of the adductors more than flexibility. There are lots of side to side motions. Think tennis but smaller movements. Lots of changing direction, reflex training, full body twists for swings, etc. Also I read somewhere that pickleball is one of the most "dangerous" sport in that there's the highest injury rate compared to#of players. I'm sure there's a caveat to that stat, maybe the highest rate in racket sports or something. Double check me on that. But there's definitely a huge patient population for us in pickleball!

**Original Post:**
For those who run their PT practices out of other businesses like gyms, wellness facilities, chiropractic offices, etc,. what should I expect to pay to rent or lease space on a monthly basis? This would be very part time to begin - less than 15 hours per week. I know this will vary by location, but wanting some averages to go off of for negotiations.

Edited to add: this will be in the Midwest near Kansas City, MO. And a shared space not my own.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** RE is so location dependent that your best bet is to find out the local per sq foot rate is and go from there.

> **Response 2:** Another thing to consider is will the space be completely yours? So can you leave marketing materials up in the common area even when you are not there? Or is it a shared space that you will only be renting hourly/as needed? 

I recommend trying to negotiate an hourly rate or fixed lease amount instead of paying a percent of what you are makingâ€¦ the country club I rent from wanted me to do 70/30 with them but I asked for a fixed amount and they agreed to $650/month. Iâ€™m in California so this was very reasonable. Iâ€™m now making 8-10k a month so I definitely got the better end of the deal by not agreeing to go 70/30

**Original Post:**
I approached a community center to use a portion of their pool to see patients for aquatic therapy. They are asking for 30% of revenue.
1) is this legal in healthcare, to pay a portion of revenue, especially if any of their members were to come to me for treatment?
2) is it just me or is 30% ridiculously high?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** 30% is fairly standard. 20-40% is normal range, but can go to 50/50 even depending on what's included etc.

> **Response 2:** It can depend on your state. In some places it's not legal for them to charge you more than what would be considered a reasonable lease rate, in those states a percentage could get the facility in trouble. Some places charge providers a flat fee per hour with a monthly capped charge.

She does have a noticeable dextroscoliosis of her lumbar spine.  Over the last month or 2 she has developed pain in right buttock, occasional n/t down lateral right leg with insidious onset. I just found myself either making up for that time off on another day & as far as free time I found myself working way more from home on documenting then I wanted. & then making calls & scheduling is a whole other headache. Not trying to discourage you just giving my experience on trying HH ðŸ˜…..I lasted two months then went back to OP

> **Response 2:** I was OP, then had a baby and switched to HH 2 decades ago. Last year I went back to OP, but may eventually wander back into HH for the flexibility and money. I wanted a mental challenge by going back to OP (boy, did I get one!) but also was missing camaraderie as HH is very isolating. OP these days is so much more of a grind, and everyone is so stressed. Our clinic has staggered lunches so fun interactions are minimal. HH can be overwhelming (as any new setting would be), but being one on one is such a blessing. Just know that motivation to improve is often much less in HH; many of those folks are fine to be completely sedentary and never perform an HEP, as long as they can make it from the recliner/bed to the toilet/bsc. Good luck! There are definitely advantages to both settings!

This is an official Medicare government test you must take to sell Medicare advantage plans   Read that and tell me if it makes any sense ðŸ‘€ keep in mind. This is a 2026 test because open enrollment starts this week.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Wow! That is interesting. Havenâ€™t heard a thing about HH services being limited at 100 days/year. But if Iâ€™m being honest, this wouldnâ€™t surprise me in the slightest. Itâ€™s limited in SNF. OP coverage is limited by many insurances. Why not HH?

> **Response 2:** Its the basis of how medicare works and advantage plans follow the guildelines they just "manage" it a lot more. Medicare A/"advantage" A allows for up to 100 days of consecutive services (typically paid at days 1-20 100%, then often 80% after. If all consecutive services are used the patient has 60 days were they must remain out of the hospital to reset med A benefits. Although i did have one patient that exhausted his lifetime medicare A benefits which is wild. Med B benefits never really go out. Where these "advantage plans" screw you though is they really like to dictate how much therapy theyre willing to give under both a & b and it has to often be pre-authorized and sometimes they even dictate what codes we use vs medicare who lets us do our thing and give the best services we can. ### Discussion 1515: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT]

**Original Post:**
What advice would you give to a therapist who wants to be uncaged?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Answer three questions: WHY and WHY and WHAT.... Why do you want to be UNCAGED for yourself? What is in it for you and your family (or future family).  WHY does YOUR practice have to exist in the community?  WHAT is it that you do for people. Then..... BELIEVE in yourself. Understand what your PASSION is. Display ACTIVE PATIENCE.  Maintain your GRIT.  Finally, truly, save yourself time, money (in the long run), and a world of frustration by having a guide/mentor/coach who has done it to lead you.

> **Response 2:** Hire a business coach.  They help rocket your business forward faster and with less guesswork.  They have several proven processes because they've been there and have already helped others.
You're going to make your own mistakes no matter what, but you can avoid the ones they've already made. They know how to coach past them. 
David Bayliff , who runs this page has an incredible program. Free knowledge is great, but it only takes you so far.
You need to invest in your knowledge by hiring a coach. 
I am in my 3rd practice. A formal coaching group was the best investment I ever made.

Just some PSAs for y'all.

When applying for a new job, can the new employer see or have access to previous salary. Iâ€™m leaving my current employer to go to a clinic where in my interview they mentioned I would qualify for up to $15 per hour more. ï¿¼

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** They can call your old employer and ask for salary, but they may not do that, and your old employer may not give them the information even if they ask.  That would be the only way for them to get that info.  There are a lot of "what if's" in that scenario.

But my question is-- why do you care if they know?  It's irrelavent what you made before.  If the new employer is offering to pay more, and/or your old employer was underpaying you, that's obviously why you want to leave (and a very good reason to leave at that).  The only numbers that are important here are the standard/average pay for a therapist with your education and experience in your area, and the cost of living in your area.  Demand what you're worth, and don't let them dictate that to you!

2 units 97112
total = $100

**Community Responses:**

 1 unit Therex $100

### Discussion 1553: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-05-01 13:51:09 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 16 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1730941781010380/

**Original Post:**
Hi everyone
Iâ€™m checking UHC insurance benefits and I always get confused when it says no referral required and no visit limits. Does it mean I can see patient without a doctorâ€™s referral , no signed POC and however long the patient needs? Insurance also says do not charge $35 co-pay. Sheâ€™s a neuro patient . Please advise, I am not trying to beat the system, I just need guidance because Iâ€™m new to this. Thank you

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Typically then you'd follow your state practice act. Always follow the strictest rule

> **Response 2:** Q: Checking insurance benefits and I always get confused when it says no referral required, and no visit limits. 
Can I see the patient without a doctorâ€™s referral, no signed POC and however long the patient needs? 

No referral means it's not an HMO plan that would need a referral. 
Check your state direct access laws, we have 20 days or 10 visits whichever is sooner without a script, and a script from a doctor is needed to have the insurance pick it up. And also charts need a doctor's signed POC/eval and re-evals.
You have to be able to show progress, and it be a skilled therapy needed and not maintenance care. Otherwise if there's a plateau (after one re-eval already having a flare up) they may try their HEP on their own a bit, because insurance may reject payment and the bill may fall to the patient.
Also unlimited visits may also have a money cap if it's Medicare, which is about 30 visits before the chart would be audited and modifiers need to be added each time. 
Was told some neuro can be tough because can be auto immune dx e.g. M.S. where it does not always steadily improve. But working in Ortho, I don't have all the insurance and outs.

### Discussion 1582: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-06-01 01:35:41 | **Topic:** 16-general-qa-advice
**Engagement:** 3 reactions, 15 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1481994685905092/

**Original Post:**
Anyone have treated pts with POTS  I have limited experience but want to help this patient and her MD both suffer from this. Or if you can point me to go links or educational places to learn to effectively treat this better.  Thanks very much

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** A PT with POTs here, I've used the Modified CHOP protocol with success for myself, but I wasn't already super deconditioned. 

For my patients, the protocol is often too much too soon for them, but your goals are to stay below manageable levels of symptoms and ideally build strength/cardio in semireclined or reclined positions before standing. 

Also fyi: exercise often can decrease the amount of heart rate increase with activity, and increases a person's capacity, but many will still have symptoms right when they stand, or if they have to stand still (store checkout lines still luck for me)

> **Response 2:** I have treated a patient with EDS & POTS it was a very slow transition over the course of weeks and tolerance varied each visit. We started mostly in hooklying-> slightly elevated-> perched at edge of table progressing to standing next to table with frequent rests, checking BP and she increased tolerance to recumbent bike.
The EDS website has lots of great information on POTS as well.

# *Investment vs. Expense*
## ***6 questions to ask yourself!***

*Starting and growing a business can often feel like a financial strain.*

*How we approach the way in which we look at the purpose of the money being spent from a mindset point can change everything for us.*

*It is pretty well understood what expenses are.*

*In short, an expense is something that costs you money without the opportunity for further growth or time freedom.*

*Investments are when the money spent towards a thing, a service, or even an employee is going to reward us and/or the practice on the backend.*

*In essence, it gives us our time back and/or makes us/the business money.*

*When money is on the table, or being considered, a great question to start with is: Will this (thing putting the money towards) impact our business in a significant way to where we can afford NOT to do it?*

*So often, the first question is can we afford it?  That question can be detrimental because this is attacking it just like you would an expense.*

*There are 5 more questions to ask that will help you to decide if the money potentially being spent is an investment or an expense.*

*Will this give us the ability to serve our customers better? Yes or No?*

*Will it improve my/our ability and knowledge of growing and running the business?*

*Will it help free up more time for me/my employees?*

*Will it make a difference in how satisfied our customers are?*

*Will it help to differentiate me/my practice in the market, and make me/the practice more different than I/it already am/is?*

*Answering â€œYesâ€ to any of these questions is a good indicator that the money is going to help make the business better for (us) and for (our) customers.*

*When we immediately write off things (say â€œNoâ€) because it doesnâ€™t fit in the budget, then we are approaching them with an expense mindset.*

*Send me a DM if you are ready to invest in yourself!*

### Discussion 1654: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-07-20 15:38:38 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 15 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1284674722303757/

**Original Post:**
Superbill question.  

I'm a PT working in home with infants, fully OON.  I charge a flat rate regardless of session length.  I use Jane and don't have many families wanting superbills, but when I do I had initially been inputting codes without itemized costs and it generally worked.  Now I have my second case asking for itemized cost by code.  My visits are most often around an hour so I just divided my flat rate that way and it worked for the previous baby that always worked out to 4 units, but this baby's visits have fluctuated more, so I'm not sure what I'm supposed to do.  If I say it's 31.25 per unit that works for most sessions but there have been some with only 2 or 3 units but I still charged 125... so there is a gap.  

Doesn't seem correct to keep changing the itemized code cost.

I keep seeing people say to use prompt pay discount to arrive at their flat rate fee, but that would require me to falsely jack up my itemized cost and always then discount it (by varied amounts)?  
... But that also doesn't seem right

Sorry for the overexplain, hopefully it made sense.  Thanks for reading! ðŸ˜…

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Iâ€™ve been there tooâ€¦ I unfortunately just charged a lesser rate (2-3 units instead of 4) for those sessions. It doesnâ€™t happen often.

> **Response 2:** I would make your itemized cost equal per unit and equal the lesser unit amount and then apply discounts if the unit amounts were higher than anticipated.  E.g. $125 cash typically gets 30 minutes or 2 units, but I went for 38 minutes this visit and per 8 minute rule I could charge 3 units, but I gave a discount for the third unit, so no charge for patient Ed, but charge for neuroreed 1 unit at 62.50 and therex at 1 unit 62.50 rates. Pretty sure you can have void units on activities you don't want to bill a full unit on Jane e.g. 7 minute activity is 0 units, but still doc the activities and cite it as no charge ðŸ˜‰ just follow 8 minute rule, match number if units to total time (60 minute session is typically 4 units),  err on side if caution. People are usual pleased with discounts or write off, but frown in session to session breakdown discrepancies like there 1 unit was this amount and now it is more expensive... hope this helps

Hello. Now that I am credentialed with Medicare, will I need to be credentialed with each separate Medicare advantage plan such as Aetna Medicare in order to fully be paid?Thank you.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Hi. Crucial clarification here: Is the Aetna plan a supplemental? (I think it'll say so on their insurance card.)

You only ever need to be in network with the primary payer -- the primary payer will automatically send the remainder of the (approved) bill to the supplemental. You'll get a check in the mail from the supplemental later; timing varies. 

If the Aetna plan is their primary plan, then it's a Medicare replacement. Don't bother going in network with those, generally speaking, unless you have really good reasons. If their plan has OON benefits for PT, they reimburse at the same rates as Medicare would have. 

Please feel free to set up a call with me if you need more guidance -- since we've chatted about some of these things already.

> **Response 2:** understabd Medicare (dis)Advantage plans are NOT MEDICARE.  They are commercial insurance.  So if you are going to hassle with them then yes you will have to credential with each one.  Unless they have OON BENEFITS and you want to hassle witg that!  Good luck.  Sorry for my negative bias regarding said Disadvantage plans.  ðŸ¤£

**Original Post:**
Will anyone share with me the form they give patients to sign if they have Medicare but are using you for cash pay? 
Thanks so much!
Edited to add: they already use medicare services but want extra hours of cash PT each week outside of their medicare services

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** You must bill Medicare for medically necessary skilled therapy services. Clients are not allowed to pay cash for these services. If they are received wellness services (be clear on how you define this) that are not covered by Medicare then there is no form that they need to sign.  If the services might normally be covered but do not meet the skilled therapy medically necessary code outlined in Section 220.2 of CMS Chapter 15 then  you will need to have the client sign an ABN. Here is the link to Chapter 15 https://www.cms.gov/Regulations-and-Guidance/Guidance/Manuals/downloads/bp102c15.pdf   Here is a link on how to correctly complete an ABN. https://www.cms.gov/Medicare/Medicare-General-Information/BNI/Downloads/ABN-Form-Instructions.pdf

> **Response 2:** Its a complete scam that medicare specificly names professions that can't opt out while saying others can for no reason at all. It's completely discriminatory and unconstitutional.

### Discussion 1718: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-06-18 22:54:52 | **Topic:** 08-legal-compliance-regulations
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 15 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1493422011429026/

**Original Post:**
Wondering if anyone has ever continuously used ChatGPT to treat a patient? I have a PI patient whose attorney is refusing to seek translator services because â€œtechnology is enough.â€
This patient had a consult with an ortho that refers to me and he said it was a disaster with communication because nothing was translating over correctly (Korean to English and vice versa). He actually told the attorney he cannot see this patient unless an actual interpreter is present and has not heard back.
Wondering if I should do the same or if anyone has had success utilizing it?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** This is a title VI issue. 

You are actually required by law to provide a qualified translator for this patient. Google translate it chat GPT or even a family member of the patient would not meet the requirement. In the event a translator is not provided, the patient could sue for discrimination. In the event of a poor outcome or injury, the patient could sue claiming negligence... which makes sense really. You can't treat without an eval and you can't really evaluate properly f you can't communicate.

The big sticker here is who pays for the translator. I've had to eat the cost when the Medicare is the payer since they won't reimburse for it.

You can Google and see some legal precedent. Off the top of my mind I can recall a case where an OBGYN was sued for discrimination for not providing an interpreter and another where an ER doctor was sued because a family member of the patient mistranslated something which led to delayed treatment and poor outcome.

> **Response 2:** Comprehend Health is an AI medical scribe that works with over 57 languages. It can listen to the conversation and input the transcript from the conversation into English. There are quite a few PTs in AZ using it now with their Spanish speaking clients and having good success. Plus it autofills in your EMR based on the transcript so you can truly focus on just treating. 

Like someone said above though, as a medical provider, I believe you have to offer interpreter services.

After my client with Parkinsonâ€™s has been hospitalized for over a week with limited PT due to â€œshort staffedâ€, the family paid me cash to come and get her sitting at EOB to finally get her in a position other than supine. 

Checking in at the hospital entrance for Covid screening consisting of a question, â€œDo you have any Covid symptoms?â€ was none other thanâ€¦ a Doctorate of Physical Therapy.

Seeking advice. Long story, any advice is appreciated. 11 year PT, home health and snf experience. 

This Coming January I'm going to need to take some fmla to be home with my son who is fighting leukemia (all is going as well, but it's a 2.5 year tx). My wife has to go back to work as a teacher in January to keep her job after taking an extended 1 year leave for our sons treatments. Fortunately, if all goes to plan, I should only have to take 3-4 full months off, then he can start going back to school. I'm in nevada, have my llc, type 1 and 2 npi and have dabbled in cash pay in home private services but home health has kept me more than busy and i havent pursued cash pay much. I'm looking at maybe trying to do some cash pay or considerin what it would take to do cash pay/ insurance hybrid while I'm off on fmla after my wife gets home from work. I live in a semi rural area but live 30-45 min from larger areas. How hard was it for everyone to build up a cash clientele and how hard was it for others to break into the referral/insurance realm? Any suggestions on where to start. I have some ideas but thought ideas from like minded individuals could be beneficial. I would like to just supplement my wife's income initially and return to home health ,but if things took off I'd not be opposed. These are just my initial brainstorming thoughts. I may opt to do a long overdue shoulder labrum repair and use some short term disability as well during that time. I am currently a Medicare/ cash mobile PT in Florida.  I have been growing for the last few years, but exploded this January when I started to take Medicare (even though that is only about 30-40% of my business).  

I have a PTA starting in July, and will ramp up my marketing in the next week or so to get her schedule filled. So far my growth has been word of mouth.  

I have found a brick and mortar that is near our small townâ€™s downtown, and I have fallen in love with the space. But, I have no idea where I would start to figure out if I can make it happen financially, and fill it.

How do I go about projecting numbers/ financials for a new hire and a space.  Also, things like.. is it a good size, a good price (i have looked at other listings nearby and it is comparable)? Is there a way to objectively figure out if it will be profitable enough to incur this new overhead and possible headahces associated with leasing?

Also is there a magic formula to determine when I am able to â€œafford it.â€.  I.E. 3-6 month emergency fund (dave ramsey style), have a wait list, have a certain % in savings, etc. 

Thanks so much.  I am super comfortable with being mobile, and it is working very well. However, I am a dreamer and this space has me thinking of ALL the possibilities for growth.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Cautionary tale here. I overestimated how many non insured or OON clients I would have and have ended up with 95% Medicare. I am not even close to covering all of my expenses and am now trying to break my lease after only 2 of 5 committed years w/o declaring bankruptcy so I can shift to a less expensive location. Covid really changed building occupancy. I was told my building was 95% leased. The building is practically empty because entire floors are empty. I donâ€™t get the young professionals in I was anticipating. Construction started across 2 streets and took all of the parking I thought I would have. I should have fought harder for a true break lease clause.

> **Response 2:** You really just have to run the numbers. Come up with your average reimbursement per visit (and I always low ball this). Come up with what your expenses will be once you hire (and I always overestimate this). You can also underestimate how many visits you and the PTA will have total per week. If the numbers still work, then youâ€™re good.

**Original Post:**
Distraction- the first of the great killers of your business. 

There's an amazing phenomenon that happens as you start to see opportunity around you. Similar to how you start to see the car you want to buy all over, opportunity starts to show up all over the place as well. 

As a staff PT, there's no reason to see opportunity so we often close off our minds to the possibility that there are opportunities outside the traditional staff PT position. 

More and more people are starting to see that this isn't the only option and that they can become "UNCAGED." Then they start a practice and hear all the different things that everyone in this and other groups are doing and there's a level of FOMO that happens that makes us think that we need to pursue every opportunity around us. 

One of the most important things that you can do as a business owner is figure out what's working, find the opportunity (not generally the opportunities) that you want to pursue and then focus and be engaged in that and not let yourself get distracted. 

People often think coaching is only for people who need help figuring out opportunities and strategy but one of the less valued but extremely important aspects of a coach is to help keep you focused on what's the most important.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** SO TRUE!! Many recognize that the greatest value in having a coach is to keep them focused! ðŸ™Œ

### Discussion 1800: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-07-19 15:11:30 | **Topic:** 15-networking-community
**Engagement:** 26 reactions, 0 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1013632806074618/

**Original Post:**
We just got back from rafting the Grand Canyon and I had one of the most resonating experiences I've had in a very long time. Spilling my guts here but I think this group will appreciate the sentiment as well as anyone. 

When I was in college, I had the amazing fortune of working as a river guide for 5 years on the Colorado River, mostly in the Grand Canyon. That job prepared me for working as a PT and especially as a small business owner better than almost any other life experience. 

Rafting the Grand Canyon requires traversing a nearly 300 mile long stretch of river that includes some of the biggest whitewater in North America. We use these huge 37 foot, 4 ton, motorized rafts that can carry up to 20 people at a time. 

I applied for my permit to do this in 1997(!), which was the last year I guided and when I was first starting PT school. It's safe to say that I was going into this a bit rusty because there I was, 25 years later, piloting one of those huge motorized rafts, carrying 16 of my family and friends for 10 days, through historically low water.

As intimidated as I was going into this, one of the best things was how awesome it was to  F E E L the Support and Camaraderie from the other boaters down there, both private and commercial. Mistakes are going to happen and we need each other. Everyone has to camp somewhere at night and we have to unofficially coordinate who is staying where. 

The private trips were smaller and scattered around, most of them hadn't really done it before. The big commercial outfitters were pushing through with their huge groups, either in their motor rigs or with groups of up to 6 smaller rafts. But everyone is a part of the community. Everyone has to work together.

That feeling of support and camaraderie I felt in the Grand Canyon is extremely similar to what I feel in this user group. 
It's the feeling I get when I work with other practice owners who are trying to make their way. 
It's the feeling I get when I volunteer with the Private Practice Section of the APTA. 
And it's the feeling I get when I volunteer for our Home Health and Hospice Association or our local Climbing Advocacy Group.

With so many people running through the Grand Canyon at any given time, things could be a lot more competitive. Fortunately, it was absolutely refreshing and impressive to be a part of a community in which the guides and boatmen from each company and private trip work together to look out for each other. This was true for helping each other through the low water runs as well as for coordinating who was camping where each night.

I'd never seen water that low. Somehow, at every turn, another boatman had my back. This stuff is not easy. 
It's very technical. 
Sometimes it's extremely hot. 
Sometimes there are storms that bring thundering flash floods. 
Sometimes other people get stuck on the rocks and we have to help pull them off.

All of that feels extremely similar when I have random employment questions or regulatory or billing questions. The other 'guides' on our trip are incredibly positive as they rally with each other so we all get down safely.

There is an amazing community experience down in the Grand Canyon! There are also amazing communities here in Uncaged, with the Private Practice Section and with the other associations we have out there.  

Thanks to everyone for looking out for each other! What a cool thing to be a part of!

They owned equipment, hired caregivers, had two other family members and patient was being seen by home health intermittently previously. **Original Post:**
Hi everyone!
I am collaborating with a family-friendly gym to provide a workshop and then an 8 week class focused on pelvic floor and returning to the gym postpartum. The goal being that at the end of the 8 weeks, participants feel comfortable joining the regular group classes without discomfort, leaking, or doubting that they can keep up because they will know how to modify movements. The workshop will be one hour and used to draw interest to get people to sign up for the class. 
I would love your thoughts and ideas on what should be included in either the workshop or the class itself. This is my first time partnering in the community like this!
Thank you so much in advance.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Try to offer it at a time of day where moms are most likely to be able to find coverage for the baby (e.g., evenings) - this was a huge barrier for me postpartum if classes were mid day

> **Response 2:** Fellow PFPT here. I think in the workshop Iâ€™d hit the whatâ€™s common vs normal piece first (leaking, pain, hyper mobility, etc). I just took a class where we talked about teaching people how to palpate sit bones and pubic and tail bone to help visualize and feel for a pelvic floor contraction. I like that since you obviously canâ€™t do a real PF exam in a group setting. 
Iâ€™d focus on teaching some general recruitment, coordination, and relaxation activities focusing on breath, TA, and PF (canister). Then you can build on that with functional movement in your actual class. 
This sounds like such a fun opportunity for you!

**Original Post:**
Here is an entrepreneurial story that I believe all of us can learn from:

There once were two bakeryâ€™s next to each other in my town. Nothing Bundt Cakes and Swirl Bakery. They sit less than 50 feet away from each other.

If any of you know Nothing Bundt Cakes, you know what you are getting when you walk in: Delicious cakes, ready to go, and a great experience. Everyone who works there is always so kind and ready to serve.  Ever notice how they even come around from the counter to greet you when you walk in?

Then there is Swirl Bakery: a fantastic bakery. They had cakes, cookies, cupcakes, scones, breadsâ€¦everything you could possibly imagine. Everything was really good there. It was just an okay experience when you walk in, depending on who was working. 

So, what can we get from this?

Two things:

1) The power that comes from being EXCEPTIONAL at one thing. What is that for you and your company?

2) The difference it truly makes when you are greeted with a smile EVERY TIME you come in.

Now, I donâ€™t know why they actually closed down. But, they were in our town for more than 10 years and I would be led to believe as a customer than 1 (or both) of the above reasons led to them closing up shop.

*Faith *

*Family *

*Fitness *

*Finance *

*Fulfillment*

The 5 F's represent your core.
